Borrower

Islamic Republic of Pakistan

Project Description

Classification

Economic growth.

Assessment

Rationale

trade 

finance 

The Project will improve trade financing and export performance by (i)
funding  a  new  dollar-based 
facility  with  credit
enhancement  accessible  to  direct,  indirect,  and  emerging  exporters,
and  particular  attention  to  the  needs  of  small-  and  medium-size
enterprises (SMEs); (ii) providing a partial risk guarantee by the Asian
Development  Bank  (ADB),  with  a  Government  counterguarantee  to
cover  sovereign  risks  associated  with  the  opening  of  letters  of  credit
(L/Cs)  by  Pakistan  importers;  (iii)  establishing  the  Pakistan  Export
Finance  Guarantee  Agency  Limited  (PEFG)  to  cover  preshipment
performance  risks  and  issue  bankable  collateral  to  SME  exporters;
and  (iv)  providing  a  technical  assistance  (TA)  cluster  for  institutional
strengthening  of  the  Export  Promotion  Bureau  (EPB).  The  Project
forms part of the Government’s Trade, Export Promotion, and Industry
(TEPI) Program supported by ADB.

Category B.
Environmental implications of the Project were reviewed and an initial
environmental  examination  completed;  environmental  interventions
have been incorporated as required.

To  significantly  reduce  poverty,  Pakistan  must  increase  its  per  capita
growth  rate  to  about  5  percent  annually  on  an  equitable  and
sustainable  basis.  Development  of  SMEs  and  exports  will  play  an
important  role.  SMEs  tend  to  dominate  labor-intensive  sectors  and
their  growth  can  provide  a  major  source  of  employment.  They  also
tend  to  be  more  efficient  than  large-scale  firms  in  certain  sectors.  To
reap  the  benefits  from  their  specialization,  SMEs  need  to  be  given  a
level  playing  field  to  compete  effectively,  including  in  international
markets. Given Pakistan’s low share of international trade, significant
economic  gains  can  be  achieved  by  increasing  exports.  Improving
for  Pakistan’s
export  performance 
macroeconomic stabilization.

is  also  an 

important 

factor 

Under the TEPI Program, improvement of the export financing system,
in  particular  for  SMEs  and  the  development  of  value-added  products
and  new  markets,  was  identified  as  a  key  area  to  increase  exports.
Numerous  SMEs  have  little  room  for  capital  expansion  and  product
upgrading  because  of  small  margins,  high  financing  cost,  and  heavy
collateral  requirements.  In  addition,  many  SMEs  are  not  familiar  with
trade  finance  instruments  and  the  benefits  they  can  bring.  By
improving  access  to  trade  finance,  much  needed  capital  for  business
expansion can be generated. Importantly, the Project builds on several
other  initiatives  being  implemented  under  the  TEPI  Program  for  a
comprehensive assistance package to facilitate SME exports.

ii

The Project’s goal is to contribute to higher growth, employment, and
exports  by  supporting  the  development  of  new  export  markets  and
products,  and  increase  SME  exports.  This  will  be  achieved  by  (i)
improving the export finance mechanism to extend availability of credit
to SMEs, (ii) reducing import L/C confirmation and transaction costs to
import  goods  needed  for  export  production,  (iii)  reducing  collateral
burden  and  effective  risk  mitigation  for  SME  preshipment  financing
requirements,  and  (iv)  improving  institutional  support  for  export
promotion and administration of the export incentive framework.

The  Project  comprises  four  components:  (i)  establishment  of  a  new
dollar-based  export  financing  facility,  the  Foreign  Currency  Export
Finance Facility (FCEF); (ii) provision of a partial risk guarantee (PRG)
for L/C confirmation of imports that are required for export production;
(iii)  equity  investment  in  the  PEFG;  and  (iv)  TA  for  Institutional
Strengthening of EPB.

A  loan  of  $150  million  for  funding  of  the  new  FCEF  facility  will  be
provided  from  ADB’s  market-based  loan  window  in  dollars,  with  a
maturity  of  15  years  and  a  3-year  grace  period.  The  loan  will  carry
interest at a floating rate based on the six-month London interbank offer
rate or, at the Government’s option, a fixed rate based on ADB’s fixed-
rate borrowing in dollar terms at the time of disbursement, plus 60 basis
points.  The  Borrower  will  be  given  a  one-time  option  to  convert  the
floating rate portion of its loan into a fixed-rate loan or vice versa. The
loan  will  carry  a  1  percent  front-end  fee  and  standard  commitment
charges.

SBP will relend the foreign exchange funds from the FCEF facility loan
to  participating  commercial  banks  (PCBs)  at  its  cost  of  funds.  The
onlending  rate  by  PCBs  to  subborrowers  will  be  determined  by  the
PCBs based on SBP guidelines commensurate with the cost and risks
of  subloans,  for  a  maximum  maturity  of  180  days.  Any  foreign
exchange  risk  will  be  borne  by  the  subborrowers.  The  PCBs  will
through  dollar-
encourage  subborrowers 
denominated (inland) L/Cs or forward cover.

those  risks 

to  cover 

SBP has set up an apex unit to deal with subloan requests under the
Director  for  Banking  Supervision.  The  PCBs  will  draw  on  the  FCEF
facility on a first-come, first-served basis, based on the subborrowers
application. The apex unit will also monitor loan utilization.

The  loan  will  be  disbursed  to  SBP  into  a  special  account  in  three
disbursements.  The  first  disbursement  of  $30  million  will  be  released
upon  loan  effectiveness.  The  two  subsequent  disbursements  will  be
based  on  the  use  of  the  FCEF  facility  and  an  estimate  of  future
demand.  Up  to  $60  million  for  each  disbursement  will  be  released
upon  80  percent  usage  of  the  preceding  disbursements,  subject  to

iii

performance.

SBP  guidelines  will  require  subborrowers  to  demonstrate  that  the
procurement  procedures  applied  for  procuring  imported  inputs  are  in
accordance with normal commercial practices and acceptable to ADB.
Only  expenditures  on  inputs  that  are  produced  in  and  supplied  from
ADB member countries are eligible for financing.

ADB  will  guarantee  payment  to  international  confirming  banks  by
Pakistan  issuing  banks  of  the  face  value  of  an  eligible  import  L/C,  if
that  payment  is  not  made  as  a  result  of  a  guaranteed  risk,  including
restriction  on 
transferability
foreign  exchange  convertibility  and 
blockage.  The  PRG,  counterguaranteed  and  indemnified  by  the
Government,  will  cover  eligible  L/Cs  to  facilitate  imports  by  Pakistan
exporters,  and  will  be  promoted  in  conjunction  with  other  TEPI
Program  initiatives,  including  the  FCEF  facility  and  PEFG.  The
maximum  aggregate  liability  under  the  PRG  at  any  time  will  not
exceed $150 million.

ADB will charge the Government a front-end fee of up to 0.30 percent
payable on the nominal amount of the PRG limit. ADB will also charge
the Government, through the facility agent, a PRG fee of 0.40 percent
per annum on the aggregate value of the maximum liability of all L/Cs
covered under the PRG from time to time, calculated on a daily basis.
Each  guaranteed  bank  will  pay  a  fee  as  a  percent  per  annum  of  the
guaranteed  amount  for  each  L/C,  which  will  be  determined  through
discussion with the potential facility agent, potential guaranteed banks,
and  issuing  banks  prior  to  the  PRG  becoming  available,  and  which
may be changed from time to time.

ADB  will  subscribe  for  up  to  20  percent  of  the  issued  and  paid-up
PEFG  capital,  for  an  investment  up  to  the  equivalent  of  $2  million.
ADB’s equity participation will in no circumstances exceed 20 percent
of the paid-in PEFG capital. The PEFG will be established as a private
sector,  public  limited  company  driven  by  the  commercial  and  private
sector  banks  (the  sponsor  group),  and  will  be  incorporated  under  the
Companies  Ordinance.  The  sponsor  group  will  be  the  primary  PEFG
shareholders with a total equity contribution of up to $6 million.

The PEFG will function as an export credit guarantee agency; its main
business will be to issue guarantees for SMEs and emerging exporters
as a collateral substitute for preshipment finance. It may also act as an
agent for postshipment export credit insurance as well as for the PRG
and offer other export-related services.

Business  is  expected  to  reach  $100  million  per  annum  in  guarantee
volume  –  about  1  percent  of  Pakistan’s  exports  –  within  the  first  3
years.  The  PEFG  is  expected  to  break  even  on  its  operational
activities  within  3  to  4  years,  and  be  floated  on  the  stock  exchange
within 5 years; ADB will divest its shares thereafter.

iv

from 

The  TA  will  help  restructure  and  provide  institutional  development  to
EPB so that it can play an effective role in trade facilitation and export
promotion,  including  promoting  the  utilization  of  the  various  export
incentive  schemes  and  available  facilities,  and  interface  with  private
sector  trade  and  export  associations,  international  partners,  and
individual  exporters  to  support  the  development  of  new  markets.  The
TA  will  be  funded  on  a  grant  basis  not  exceeding  the  equivalent  of
the  ADB-funded  TA  program.  The  TA  will  be
$800,000 
implemented in two phases, using the cluster modality. The first phase
will be a small-scale TA to review EPB’s strategic plan and operational
priorities;  the  second  phase  will  undertake  the  capacity  building
activities  identified  in  phase  1,  with  focus  on  the  management
information  system  and  training  needs.  About  18  person-months  of
international  and  27  person-months  of  domestic  consulting  services
will  be  required.  Consultants  will  be  recruited  in  accordance  with
ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants and other arrangements
satisfactory to ADB on the engagement of domestic consultants.

The Project will increase access to credit, and reduce financing costs
of SMEs and emerging exporters that have so far been excluded from
the  export  finance  system.  The  Project  will  offer  risk  mitigation
measures  for  exporters  to  enter  into  new  markets.  This  will  increase
exports and foreign exchange earnings by more than $350 million per
annum.  The  Project  will  support  the  creation  of  about  135,000  new
jobs,  supporting  the  livelihood  of  about  1  million  persons.  The
improved balance of payments will also contribute to macroeconomic
stabilization.  The  Project  will  further  support  reform  of  the  subsidized
existing Export Finance System and prepare Pakistan to comply with
long-term World Trade Organization obligations.

Project Benefits and
Beneficiaries

 I.

THE PROPOSAL

1.
I submit for your approval the following Report and Recommendation on (i) a proposed
loan  to  the  Islamic  Republic  of  Pakistan  for  the  Foreign  Currency  Export  Finance  Facility
(FCEF); (ii) a partial risk guarantee in favor of international commercial banks that confirm import
letters of credit (L/Cs) issued by Pakistan commercial banks at the request of eligible exporters,
subject  to  a  counterindemnity  by  the  Islamic  Republic  of  Pakistan;  and  (iii)  a  proposed  equity
investment  in  the  Pakistan  Export  Finance  Guarantee  Agency  Limited  (PEFG),  for  the  Small-
and  Medium-Size  Enterprise  Trade  Enhancement  Project  in  the  Islamic  Republic  of  Pakistan.
The report also describes proposed technical assistance (TA) for the Institutional Strengthening
of  the  Export  Promotion  Bureau  (EPB)  and  if  the  proposed  loan  is  approved  by  the  Board,  I,
acting under the authority delegated to me by the Board, shall approve the TA.

II.

INTRODUCTION

Under  the  Trade,  Export  Promotion,  and  Industry  (TEPI)  Program1,  access  to  credit  for
2.
small- and medium-size enterprises (SMEs),2 emerging exporters, and nontraditional products,
in  particular,  was  identified  as  a  major  impediment  to  export  development.  To  finance  inputs
required for export production, the Government of Pakistan agreed – in addition to the existing
Export Finance System (EFS) – to introduce a dollar-based financing facility targeted at SMEs,
and  emerging,  direct  and  indirect  exporters;  and  requested  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)
assistance for its establishment. Subsequently, an ADB project team3 visited Pakistan in March,
July, and September 2000 to discuss the implementation and incentive mechanisms, including
the  need  for  a  PRG,  to  ensure  that  the  new  facility  will  best  meet  exporters’  demands.
Stakeholder  consultation  also  comprised  a  workshop  on  SME  development  organized  in  July
2000 in Lahore. The Project framework is in Appendix 1.

3.
To  address  the  collateral  problem  of  many  SMEs  in  obtaining  export  finance,  the
Government  also  agreed  to  support  the  establishment  of  a  preshipment  export  finance
guarantee  agency,  and  a  TA  loan  towards  this  end  was  approved  together  with  the  TEPI
Program.4  During  the  early  phase  of  TA  implementation,  stakeholders  indicated  a  strong
preference  to  establish  this  agency  exclusively  in  the  private  sector  rather  than  jointly  in  the
public  and  private  sector,  and  private  sector  investors  requested  support  from  multilateral
agencies including ADB and the International Finance Corporation (IFC).

III.

BACKGROUND

A.

Sector Context

1. 

Macroeconomic and Poverty Trends

a.

Performance Review

                                                
1 
2 

Loan 1680-PAK: Trade, Export Promotion and Industry Program, for $300 million, approved on 31 March 1999.
An  SME  is  defined  under  TEPI  as  an  enterprise  with  $2,500,000  equivalent  or  less  in  export  earnings  per
annum.
The core Project Team included W. Liepach, Senior Financial/Capital Markets Specialist, IWFI (Mission Leader);
R. Earman, Senior Public/Private Sector Specialist; L. Campbell, Senior Counsel; L. Ding, Trade Economist; M.
Good,  Counsel;  M.  Endelman,  Cofinancing  Officer;  S.B.  Koh,  Economist;  M.  Pal,  Social  Sector  Economist;  A.
Reza, Investment Officer; M. Varkay, Investment Officer; E. Clave, Associate Project Analyst.
Loan 1681-PAK: Institutional Strengthening of the Trade Regime, for $3 million, approved on 31 March 1999.

3 

4 

 2

The  past  two  years  have  been  difficult  for  Pakistan’s  economy.  Following  the  country’s
4.
nuclear tests in late May 1998, the virtual suspension of new official development assistance led
to erosion of investor confidence and the almost complete cessation of private capital flows. This
compounded  longstanding  socioeconomic  difficulties,  economic  growth  declined  steeply,  and
poverty  incidence  increased.  Temporary  emergency  measures  were  required  to  conserve
foreign exchange and address the mounting pressure on the balance of payments; in early 1999
external debt payments were rescheduled. The country’s economic performance since then has
shown a slow but fragile recovery. The gross domestic product (GDP) increased to 4.8 percent
in fiscal year (FY) 2000, 1.7 percent higher than in FY1999. This is mainly due to good cotton
and foods-grain harvests. Inflation remains low, averaging about 3.6 percent, largely because of
better  food  supply  and  slow  monetary  growth.  However,  the  Government  is  experiencing
difficulties  in  containing  the  fiscal  deficit,  which  was  at  6.1  percent  of  GDP  in  FY2000,  two
percentage points higher than originally forecast.5

5.
The balance of payments situation remains one of the principal areas of concern. During
FY2000, the trade deficit reached $1.7 billion, up 4.4 percent from the previous year and more
than double the Government’s $800 million target. Although exports expanded by 8.7 percent to
nearly  $8.5  billion,  imports  also  increased  by  8  percent  to  $10.2  billion,  largely  due  to  higher
prices  of  petroleum  and  related  products.  Remittances  were  down  by  about  10  percent  and
foreign direct investment decreased by 4 percent in FY2000 compared with the previous year.
The widened trade gap, coupled with a negative resource transfer from development agencies
has  exerted  pressure  on  the  balance  of  payments  position.  To  contain  the  foreign  exchange
gap, the State Bank of Pakistan (SBP) had to purchase large amounts of dollars from the open
market.  The  foreign  exchange  reserves  remained  stable  at  around  $1.2  billion  during  most  of
FY2000,  equivalent  to  only  five  weeks  of  imports.  Due  to  absence  of  significant  inflows  during
the  first  quarter  of  FY2001,  reserves  dropped  to  only  about  $1.0  billion  in  October  2000.  To
improve this fragile situation, increasing exports is a top priority.

In FY2000, Pakistan’s export performance improved over the previous year, although it
6.
remained short of the $9 billion target. The improvement was aided by favorable domestic and
external  events.  On  the  domestic  front,  the  bumper  cotton  crop  and  its  reduced  prices
contributed  to  a  buoyant  textile  sector,  the  country’s  most  important  export  industry.  Exports
were aided by the recovery of the global economy, in particular by the East Asian economies, as
well  as  continued  strong  growth  in  the  United  States  (US)  and  Europe.  Demand  for  Pakistan
products  increased  in  major  export  markets.  Export  performance  during  the  first  quarter  of
FY2001  has  been  encouraging,  at  about  15  percent  higher  than  the  previous  year.  However,
competition  in  Pakistan’s  key  markets  increased  as  well,  and  average  prices  of  many  export
products  fell  mainly  because  of  increased  competition,  and  the  stronger  dollar.  To  continue  to
increase exports, Pakistan needs to improve its competitiveness, expand its narrow export base,
and develop new products and markets.

b.

Prospects and Priorities

7.
The  medium-term  prospects  for  Pakistan’s  economic  growth  and  ultimately  for
sustainable poverty reduction through increased employment opportunities depend critically on
policy consistency, pace of economic reforms, good governance, and transparency in decision
making.  Equally  important  are  the  perceptions  and  assistance  of  the  international  donor

                                                
5 

For  a  more  comprehensive  assessment  of  economic  issues  and  performance,  see  CER:  PAK  98013: Country
Economic Review, Pakistan,  November  1998;  and  IN.67-99: Pakistan: Country Operational Framework 1999-
2000, March 1999.

 3

community  and  the  private  sector.  Macroeconomic  policy  priorities  include  reducing  the  fiscal
deficit  by  broadening  the  tax  base  and  improving  revenue  collection,  improving  the  balance  of
payment  situation  by  increasing  exports,  encouraging  SMEs  to  increase  participation  in  the
formal  economy,  and  improving  public  debt  management.  The  Government  has  presented  a
comprehensive and credible policy framework for economic development and poverty reduction,
as outlined in the Economic Revival Plan presented in December 1999, the Budget for FY2001
approved in June 2000, and the Interim Poverty Reduction Strategy paper (PRSP), updated in
September  2000.  The  policies  and  plans  were  generally  well  received,  and  projected  GDP
growth  of  5  percent  in  FY2001,  inflation  at  4.5  percent,  and  reduction  in  fiscal  and  current
account  deficits  to  5  percent6  and  2  percent,  respectively.  The  export  target  was  set  at  $10
billion.  While  this  target  appears  ambitious,  about  18  percent  higher  than  the  actual  figure  in
FY2000,  it  only  represents  about  15  percent  of  GDP.  These  projections  are  based  upon
sustained increases in agriculture production, revival of the manufacturing sector, lower prices of
oil and its products, and signs of increasing competitiveness.

8.
Linked to Pakistan’s macroeconomic recovery is its ability to regain investor confidence
and  attract  foreign  capital.  In  particular,  an  understanding  of  policy  reforms  and  renewed
assistance  by  the  International  Monetary  Fund  (IMF)  is  an  important  element  to  mitigate  the
country’s  fragile  balance  of  payments  position.  A  standby  arrangement  amounting  to  $600
million is expected to be approved by IMF in November 2000, while discussions are ongoing for
more  comprehensive  packages  under  the  Poverty  Reduction  Growth  Facility  (PRGF),  which  is
expected  to  be  concluded  during  the  first  half  of  2001.  The  tariff  dispute  with  the  independent
power  producers,  which  damaged  the  country's  attractiveness  for  private  investment,  has  now
been  largely  resolved,  and  remaining  negotiations  with  Hub  Power  Company  and  Kot-Adu
Power Company are in the final phase of settlement. The recent increase in the stock exchange
index  and  renewed  foreign  portfolio  inflows  indicate  increasing  investor  confidence  and
improving economic stability. However, even under an improved macroeconomic scenario with
renewed  foreign  assistance  and  private  sector  inflows,  Pakistan  will  have  difficulty  meeting  its
debt service obligations, in particular if repayment flows return to normal as scheduled in 2001.
Thus, rescheduling of official debt under the Paris Club is expected in early 2001.

c.

Income Distribution and Poverty Trends

9.
Poverty  levels  in  Pakistan  have  drastically  increased  since  the  early  1990s  and  are
strongly correlated with the slowdown in economic growth. By contrast, during the 1980s when
economic growth was relatively high, poverty declined. During the 1990s, GDP growth declined
in comparison to the three previous decades. In the 1990s, GDP growth decreased to only 4.4
percent per annum from 6 percent per annum during the 1980s. Agricultural growth was actually
stronger  in  the  1990s  but  other  important  sectors  such  as  services,  manufacturing,  and  large-
scale  manufacturing  all  slowed  significantly.  This,  in  turn,  had  a  major  impact  on  employment,
incomes, and poverty levels.

10.
According  to  the  Government’s  PRSP,  structural  adjustment  and  macroeconomic
stabilization  programs  adopted  during  the  1990s  have  had  a  disproportionate  impact  on  the
poor.  In  particular,  heavy  indirect  taxation,  exchange  rate  fluctuations,  removal  of  subsidies
(especially  on  food),  and  adjustments  in  tariff  protection  rates  resulted  in  lower  output  and
employment  rates.  Other  related  factors  resulting  in  increased  poverty  include  stagnant
agricultural productivity, continued downward trend in levels of incoming remittances from out-of-

                                                
6 

The fiscal deficit was originally stipulated at 4.5 percent in the FY2001 Budget, and subsequently revised to 5
percent after discussion with IMF.

 4

country workers, high population growth, low human development, and rising inflation. Officially,
the  annual  inflation  rate  is  around  4  to  5  percent,  with  food  prices  accounting  for  the  highest
proportion  of  the  consumer  price  index.  The  oil  price  increase  in  FY2000  and  the  continued
depreciation  of  the  Pakistan  rupee  against  the  dollar  are  expected  to  have  a  disproportionate
negative impact the poor. While no reliable data on real wages in the SME sector exists during
the last decade real wages have been falling for all workers in all sectors. An indication of this
trend is the fact that real per capita income grew by a mere 1.3 percent from 1991 to 1999.

Pakistan  does  not  have  an  official  poverty  line.  Using  a  calorie-based  approach,  which
11.
measures poverty in terms of a household’s access to food, the Government’s PRSP estimates
that approximately 35.2 percent of the population live in poverty.  This FY1999 data is based on
provisional  results  from  the  1998/99  Pakistan  integrated  household  survey.  Rural  poverty,  at
36.0 percent of the population, is higher than urban poverty, which at 33.8 percent in FY1999 is
now nearly twice the rate of 18.6 percent estimated for FY1991.

12.
Historical  data  on  income  distribution  for  Pakistan  shows  four  distinct  phases  in  the
reduction  of  inequalities.7  Based  on  the  standard  comparison  of  the  ratio  of  the  highest  20
percent to the lowest 20 percent of household income groups (and the Gini coefficient), the data
shows income inequality narrowed during the early phase of Pakistan’s development from 1963-
1971. During the second phase, from 1971-1979 income inequality widened during a period of
economic and political instability. From 1984 to 1988, income distribution again narrowed during
a period of high economic growth of over 6 percent per annum. In the fourth phase, from 1988 to
1996, inequality in income distribution worsened significantly, in tandem with declining rates of
economic  growth.  Rural  income  distribution  has  remained  relatively  more  equal  than  urban
incomes, with rural incomes overall being lower than urban incomes, and rural poverty higher.

2.

SMEs and Export Development

SMEs  are  a  robust  and  vital  part  of  the  private  sector  and  play  an  important  role  in
13.
Pakistan’s  economy.  Many  SMEs  operate  in  the  informal  and  undocumented  sector.  This  is
particularly  the  case  for  SMEs  with  fewer  than  10  employees,  which  are  particularly  active  in
small-scale  manufacturing,  grain  milling,  and  various  services.  Data  on  the  SME  and  informal
sector  is  limited,8  although  a  recent  study9  estimates  the  informal  sector  represents  up  to  47
percent of total economic activity and 44 percent of employment, two thirds of which is in rural
areas. Many of the jobs in this sector do not require high levels of literacy, and Pakistan’s low
levels of human development do constrain the emergence of SMEs in modern sectors. Of SMEs
employing more than 10 workers, nearly half of their activities take place in grain milling, cotton
weaving,  wood,  furniture,  and  metal  products.10  The  remaining  activities  are  fairly  diverse  and
include  other  textiles,  art  silk,  carpets,  sporting  goods,  jewelry,  footwear,  electrical  equipment,
machinery, and food. Several of these activities have export potential that so far has not been
exploited.

(ISSMI 1994-95). The Lahore University of Management Sciences is currently undertaking an extensive survey
on the SME sector.

 5

Most  of  Pakistan’s  exports  are  generated  in  the  manufacturing  sector.  The  share  of
14.
manufacturing in GDP has slowly increased over the years, contributing 18.6 percent to GDP in
FY1999; about one third was contributed by SMEs.11 In the manufacturing sector, textiles is the
largest industry contributing nearly 30 percent to production, employing over 40 percent of the
manufacturing sector’s labor, and providing nearly 65 percent of the country’s exports. The food
industry (including edible oils, grain milling, sugar, animal feed, beverages, and tobacco) is the
second largest industry and provides about 14 percent of exports.

The manufacturing sector employs about 4.1 million people, about 11 percent of the total
15.
labor force; virtually all are in the private sector.12 The biggest share of the labor force, about 83
percent,  is  employed  by  SMEs.  According  to  Small  and  Medium  Enterprise  Development
Authority  (SMEDA),  as  many  as  1.8  million  jobs  could  be  created  in  SMEs  in  five  key  sectors
during  2000-2005.    These  sectors  are  textiles,  leather,  dairy,  marble,  and  fisheries;  all  have
considerable  export  potential.  However,  as  the  average  output  per  employee  is  generally  low,
often less than $3,000, even firms that are considered large by employment size actually have
low  output.  Firms  that  have  output  of  about  $2.5  million,  which  is  small  by  Western  standards
and  is  the  SME  threshold  applied  for  the  TEPI  Program,  often  employ  1,000  people  or  more.
Even  exporters  considered  large  by  Pakistan  standards  do  often  not  reach  the  minimum
threshold  demanded  by  large  international  buyers  to  enter  into  an  export  sales-supplier
arrangement.

16.
Pakistan’s  share  in  world  trade  is  disproportionally  low  and  exports  are  heavily
concentrated by sector and by client base. The textile sector dominates with about 65 percent of
all exports. In FY1999, food and food products comprised 13.8 percent, while leather and leather
products made up 6.6 percent. All other sectors comprised the remaining 15.4 percent. The five
biggest  markets  for  Pakistan  exports  accounted  for  nearly  half  of  the  total:  US  21.8  percent;
Hong Kong, China 7.1 percent; United Kingdom 6.6 percent; Germany 6.6 percent; United Arab
Emirates 5.4 percent. The export of value-added textile products was especially concentrated in
these markets. This trade structure confirms both a high degree of vulnerability and unrealized
potential. Appendix 2 provides a more detailed overview of Pakistan’s main export products and
their markets.

Over  the  years  Pakistan’s  SMEs  have  demonstrated  resilience  to  withstand  economic
17.
downturns, but unlike in some of the fast-growing East Asian economies they have not lived up
to  their  potential  as  the  engine  of  growth  and  source  of  high  value-added  and  skill  intensive
exports.  SMEs  have  tended  to  dominate  low  value-added  export  sectors  that  use  traditional
technologies.  In  the  East  Asian  economies,  SME  contribution  to  manufacturing  employment
increased  especially  when  they  broke  into  high-technology  and  skill  intensive  exports.  For
example, in Taipei, China, SMEs constituted 61 percent of the country’s dynamic export base in
1992. In Pakistan, by comparison, SMEs contribute less than 7 percent to exports for virtually all
sectors, with the exception of cotton weaving and other textiles where the share may reach 20 to
25  percent.  This  indicates  (i)  the  potential  to  increase  SME  contributions  to  overall  economic
performance,  and  (ii)  the  need  for  SMEs  to  focus  on  more  value-added  products  and  modern
production techniques if they are to be internationally competitive.

18.
The  underperformance  of  SMEs  can  be  partly  explained  by  the  lack  of  Government
assistance  and  policy  support  to  the  sector.  In  Pakistan,  the  cost  of  doing  business  in  the
informal sector, although high, is in the absence of access to the benefits of existing trade and

                                                
11

12

SMEs are defined here as employing up to 100 people.
Only about 42 manufacturing enterprises remain in the public sector, employing about 36,000 people.

 6

export incentive schemes for many SMEs still considered lower than participating in the formal
economy.  To  generate  sustainable  growth  and  employment,  the  key  challenge  will  be  to  bring
the  large  number  of  SMEs  operating  in  the  informal  sector  into  the  formal  economy  and  to
provide  incentives  for  technological  upgrading.  To  this  end,  the  Government  has  shifted  its
policy  focus  to  SME  development,  with  the  approval  of  the  TEPI  Program  and  the  Economic
Revival  Plan  announced  in  December  1999  identifying  promotion  of  small-  and  medium-scale
industries as one of the four priority areas for reviving the economy.

Recent  policy  initiatives  by  SMEDA  and  EPB  aim  to  promote  SMEs  and  nontraditional
19.
exports,  such  as,  processed  fish  and  fruits,  jewelry,  polished  stones,  electronic  goods,  and
software. While these sectors may indeed have good potential with high growth rates, they are
starting  from  a  very  low  base  and  will  take  some  time  to  reach  volumes  that  will  make  a
significant  economic  impact.  In  the  near  term,  a  shift  is  needed  to  higher  value  addition  within
product groups, in particular textiles, as well as a move into new markets for established goods,
e.g.,  in  the  sporting  goods  sector.  Huge  markets  such  as  in  Latin  America  and  Africa  remain
largely  untapped.  Similarly,  exports  of  surgical  instruments,  for  instance,  are  predominantly
focused on the US and Europe.

20.
New  investments  and  sale  efforts  in  exports  are  also  hampered  by  lack  of  market
intelligence, lack of insurance devices to spread risks, and reluctance of banks to lend for new
projects or to new markets. This is a serious problem as export expansion usually takes place in
these areas. Policymakers therefore must continue to focus on assistance to improve marketing,
technical know-how, and productivity enhancement, and to reduce overhead costs.

3.

Supply of Export Finance and the Financial Sector

21.
An  efficient  trade  finance  system  is  an  important  element  in  any  strategy  for  export
development.  The  current  Export  Finance  System  (EFS)  was  established  in  1973  and  allows
commercial  banks  to  offer  export  loans  for  preshipment  and  term  postshipment  finance  based
on  the  actual  export  L/Cs  or  the  previous  fiscal  year’s  export  performance.  The  loans  are
refinanced by SBP at a current rate of 6 percent and onlent by commercial banks to exporters at
a  preferential  interest  rate  of  about  8  percent.  SBP  revised  the  EFS  on  various  occasions.
Importantly, SBP Circular No. 44 (17 December 1998) allowed extension of the EFS to indirect,
emerging, and SME exporters, in addition to the traditional target group of large direct exporters.
In practice, however, emerging, direct, indirect, and SME exporters continue to face difficulties
accessing  the  EFS  due  to  the  cumbersome  and  lengthy  application  procedures;  commercial
banks prefer extending the EFS to their prime, large, and well-established customers with good
track records or those who can furnish physical collateral.13

22.
The  EFS  finances  about  50  percent  of  Pakistan’s  exports.  About  half  of  EFS  financing
has been extended on a transaction basis (part I), for about 32,000 transactions, with the other
half  made  available  to  established  exporters,  based  on  past  export  performance  (part  II).
Effective 1 July 2000, SBP excluded some lower value-added items, including fabrics and yarn,
from  the  EFS  and  overall  utilization  is  expected  to  fall.  EFS  procedures  tend  to  reward  long-
established  exporters  who  avail  themselves  of  the  EFS  part  II,  although  effective  utilization  is
difficult  to  trace.  Part  I,  meanwhile,  can  be  slow  and  cumbersome  to  process  in  particular  for
nontraditional  goods  or  indirect  exporters,  and  is  thus  dominated  by  high-volume  traditional
goods,  such  as  textiles  or  bulk  commodities.  Thus,  the  EFS  discriminates  against  new  and

                                                
13 

The nonprime customers of commercial banks, who cannot access the EFS, meet their needs from the general
working capital overdraft facility at prime lending rates, or raise financing against foreign bills.

 7

emerging  exporters,  and  offers  little  support  for  the  development  of  new  markets  or  new
products.

23.
The  EFS  has  a  number  of  inherent  problems  and  distortions,  and  concerns  about
utilization and effectiveness of EFS are ongoing. Most importantly, the absence of effective risk
mitigation  mechanisms  and  the  existence  of  a  banking  culture  that  does  not  accept  export
payment  instruments  (such  as  L/Cs)  as  adequate  collateral  substitution  act  as  impediments  to
the  banking  system  providing  funds  for  the  development  of  new  exporters,  markets,  and
products.  Thus  the  EFS  fall  short  of  the  potential  development  role  a  refinance  product  might
play.  SMEs that cannot meet the collateral requirements of the commercial banks are forced to
remain  in  the  informal  market  and  borrow  funds  at  prohibitively  high  rates;  this  inhibits  export
growth.

24.
Less  than  1,000  exporters  appear  to  benefit  from  the  EFS,  compared  with  30,000
registered exporters at EPB, of which about 6,000 are considered active. Thus most exporters,
and in particular SMEs, are excluded from the EFS. Approximately 35 percent of SME financing
comes from formal financial institutions (footnote 10); this is somewhat higher in the exportable
subsectors. SME access to formal credit is restricted because they are unable to meet collateral
requirements.  The  shortcomings  of  the  EFS  and  the  financial  sector  must  be  overcome  to
provide  access  to  finance  for  the    export  segment,  including  those  importing  inputs  for  export
production.

25.
On  the  import  side,  75  percent  of  Pakistan’s  imports  are  in  only  four  categories:
machinery,  22  percent;  agricultural  and  other  chemicals,  20  percent;  food,  17  percent;  and
petroleum,  16  percent.  The  import  content  for  export  goods  varies  considerably:  about  50
percent  for  surgical  goods  and  nearly  as  high  for  sports  goods,  but  lower  for  low  value-added
products. Overall, the import content for export averages about 15-20 percent, i.e., about $1.3-
$1.7 billion. Assuming an average financing period of 120 days, a total funding volume of $433
million-$566 million would be required for import financing. The funding volume would obviously
be  lower  the  shorter  the  financing  horizon  is.  The  export  volume  of  nontraditional  sectors
targeted by either SMEDA, EPB, or PEFG is currently about $1.5 billion, excluding value-added
textiles.  Assuming  a  higher  import  content  for  those  sectors,  at  about  25  percent,  financing
requirements for imported inputs into this segment amount to about $375 million, with a funding
volume of about $125 million (at three times annual turnover).

26.
Virtually all commercial banks in Pakistan have been active participants in the EFS. The
domestic private sector commercial banks have been particularly active, as trade finance is their
core  activity.  Foreign  banks  appear  to  attract  the  multinational  and  more  established  clientele,
and  on  average  show  higher  financing  amounts  per  transactions.  Excluding  the  very  large
transactions, the average EFS transaction size is about $40,000, roughly the amount it takes for
many  goods  to  fill  one  standard-sized  container  for  shipment.  More  than  half  of  the  exports
under  the  EFS,  about  54  percent,  go  to  nonmembers  of  the  Organization  for  Economic
Cooperation  and  Development  (OECD)  and  most  of  the  EFS  transactions  are  textile  related.
Much  of  this  is  for  cotton  yarn.14  In  contrast,  some  of  the  sectors  targeted  for  export
development  in  the  new  trade  policy,  such  as  fruit  and  vegetables,  electrical  equipment,  or
marble have received remarkably little financing from the EFS.

                                                
14 

Effective 1 July 2000, SBP has withdrawn access to EFS for yarn. As a result, total utilization of EFS is expected
to decline in FY2001.

 8

27. While  Pakistan  banks  prefer  L/C-based  trade,  exports  with  the  US  and  Europe  are
increasingly on an open account basis. This has two implications: (i) open account transactions
carry  a  higher  buyer  risk  that  needs  to  be  mitigated,  in  particular  if  the  buyer  represents  a
sizeable volume relative to total production volume of the exporter; and (ii) adequate ways and
means  must  be  established  to  link  the  financing  of  the  export  through  the  supply  chain  to  the
indirect exporter and the import. While L/C-based trade addresses these issues, the exporter is
under L/C based trade often exposed to long payment delays of more than 120 days and higher
financing charges occur.

28.
Since 1994, Pakistan has gradually liberalized its foreign exchange management and the
temporary  emergency  measures  instituted  following  the  nuclear  test  in  May  1998  to  conserve
foreign  exchange  have  now  been  lifted.  Exporters  and  importers  are  allowed  to  buy  and  sell
foreign  exchange  as  needed,  although  exporters  are  still  required  to  repatriate  their  export
proceeds,  given  the  weak  foreign  exchange  reserve  position.  Exporters  with  firm  contracts  (or
holding export orders or L/Cs) are allowed to raise short-term loans for 180 days and repay their
obligations from export proceeds, although this has encountered difficulties in practice. SBP also
allows  commercial  banks  to  offer  forward  cover  and  an  interbank  foreign  exchange  market  is
being developed.

29.
Unlike  many  competing  countries,  Pakistan  does  not  have  a  functioning  export  credit
agency.  An  export  credit  guarantee  scheme  was  established  within  the  state-owned  Pakistan
Insurance Corporation in the 1970s, but was virtually disbanded in 1997. The scheme never won
credibility  with  the  private  sector  as  it  offered  the  wrong  products  and  covered  the  wrong
markets inducing moral hazard, failed to pay claims, and had cumbersome and nontransparent
procedures and pricing policy.

B.

Government Policies and Plans

The  Government’s  short-  and  medium-term  development  objectives,  strategies,  and
30.
plans  are  laid  out  in  the  PRSP.  Poverty  reduction  is  the  present  Government’s  overarching
development  goal.  The  PRSP,  which  takes  into  account  the  interrelationship  of  economic,
social, and governance dimensions, outlines a four-pronged approach: (i) providing broad-based
economic  growth  to  generate  efficient  income  generating  opportunities  for  the  poor,  and  a
pattern of growth that is relatively labor intensive; (ii) achieving the highest possible growth path
consistent  with  available  financial  and  human  capital  under  a  governance  architecture  that  is
both humane and efficient; (iii) improving access to education, skill training, primary health care,
nutrition, and other social services to help the poor become productive employees give them the
skills  to  start  their  own  small  scale  business  ventures;  and  (iv)  providing  safety  nets  for
vulnerable groups.

To  correct  the  macroeconomic  imbalance  and  improve  economic  efficiency,  a  broad
31.
economic development strategy and revival plan was unveiled by the Government in December
1999. Restoring good governance is the cornerstone of the economic strategy. From a sectoral
perspective, four priority areas are identified to revive the economy: (i) revitalizing the agriculture
sector,  (ii)  promoting  SMEs,  (iii)  expanding  the  liquid  petroleum  and  gas  sector,  and  (iv)
promoting  the  information  technology  (IT)  industry.  The  new  reform  program  includes  financial
sector and capital market reform, civil service reform, judicial and legal reform, and fiscal reform.

initiatives  have  also  been  proposed

In the banking system, detailed privatization plans and disposal of the remaining shares
32.
of  the  nationalized  commercial  banks  and  other  state-owned  financial  institutions  were  drafted
and  some  actions  taken  on  the  United  Bank,  Habib  Bank,  Allied  Bank,  National  Investment
Trust,  Investment  Corporation  of  Pakistan,  National  Development  Finance  Corporation,  and
Industrial Development Bank of Pakistan. New managers from the private sector were appointed
in  most  of  the  development  financial  institutions.  A  program  was  designed  and  banking  laws
amended  to  enhance  the  minimum  capital  requirements.  SBP  will  be  restructured  to  focus
mainly  on  its  core  operations  such  as  monetary  policy,  banking  supervision,  and  foreign
exchange management. SBP’s noncore operations will be  transferred to commercial banks or
other financial institutions.

33.
To revive the current sluggish economy, export promotion is one of the most important
areas  of  concern.  The  FY2001  budget  speech  pointed  out  that  Pakistan’s  balance  of  payment
problems could be fully resolved if the country achieves an export level of $12 billion without a
significant  increase  of  imports.  In  this  context,  the  Government  announced  a  number  of
incentives  for  importers  and  exporters  in  the  new  trade  policy  by  setting  a  $10  billion  export
target for FY2001, 18 percent higher than in FY2000. To promote exports, (i) SBP will follow an
exchange rate policy to maintain its competitiveness in relation to market forces and inflationary
differentials  between  Pakistan  and  its  major  trading  partners,  (ii)  the  EFS  will  be  refocused  to
value-added exports and access of small exporters to export finance will be improved, and (iii)
the system of no-duty-no-drawback will be streamlined and made more accessible.

34.
Diversification of the export base and achievement of greater value addition in goods and
services is an important part of the new trade policy. The policy seeks to enhance the country’s
world  market  share  of  the  top  10  textile  and  nontextile  categories.  The  Government’s  focus  is
further  on  promoting  selected  nontraditional  sectors,  such  as  software,  engineering  goods,
chemicals,  fruits  and  vegetables.  A  number  of  incentives  will  be  offered  to  the  producers  of
textiles, fisheries, fruits and vegetable, rice, gems and jewelry, leather garments and products,
and software, with a view to substantially increasing the country’s exports. The trade policy also
includes measures (i) to liberalize export, (ii) extend subsidies to enterprises to 30 June 2001to
facilitate  international  standard  organization  (ISO)  certification,  and  (iii)  set  up  an  export
facilitation unit in the Central Board of Revenue.

35.
To  develop  the  SME  sector,  the  FY2001  Budget  includes  support  for  (i)  a  new  textile
sector  policy  that  redirects  the  focus  on  value-added  apparel  and  finishing  sectors;  (ii)
revitalization of the Small Business Finance Corporation to help develop SMEs; (iii) formulation
of  a  policy,  in  consultation  with  SBP,  to  ensure  adequate  flow  of  credit  to  the  SME;  and  (iv)
revitalization  of  SMEDA  and  the  preparation  of  packages  to  develop  export  capacity  in
nontraditional sectors.

The  Government’s  Three-Year  Development  Program,  2000-2003,  presents  strategic
36.

occupy  prominent  places.  Through  SMEDA,

C.

External Assistance to the Sector

38.
To  assist  the  country’s  balance  of  payments  difficulties  and  the  Government’s  reform
efforts,    IMF  is  preparing  a  standby  arrangement  for  consideration  by  its  Executive  Board  in
November 2000, and a  PRGF for consideration by the IMF board in 2001. The reform agenda
of  the  PRGF  includes  fiscal  reform;  provincial  finance  reform;  structural  changes  in  trade,
finance, energy, agriculture, industry, education, and health; reforms in governance, devolution
and  decentralization  of  powers,  and  the  judiciary;  and  private  sector  development.  In  parallel,
the  World  Bank  is  preparing  a  new  structural  adjustment  loan  that  supports  that  areas  of
governance, administrative, and banking reform, and power sector restructuring. Pakistan is also
discussing  with  the  Islamic  Development  Bank  further  assistance  for  trade  financing,  in
particular to support the import of petroleum products.

39.
In  May  2000,  the  IFC  has  approved  the  Trade  Enhancement  Project.  This  project  is
aimed at improving access to trade finance for private Pakistan businesses by credit enhancing
import  L/Cs.  It  involves  establishing  a  two-year  $100  million  revolving  facility  to  guarantee
documentary  credits  originated  by  six  selected  commercial  banks  in  Pakistan.  Through  the
facility,  these  commercial  banks  will  have  the  ability  to  have  the  L/Cs  they  issue  on  behalf  of
their  clients,  private  sector  Pakistan  businesses,  confirmed  by  ABN  AMRO  Bank  with  risk
sharing by the IFC.

40.
ADB  is  coordinating  with  IMF  and  the  World  Bank  to  ensure  that  the  policy  reforms
promoted in this Project are an integral component of a policy framework paper supported by the
PRGF  and  the  World  Bank’s  structural  adjustment  loan.  As  in  the  past,  the  major  reforms
proposed by ADB’s ongoing and forthcoming project and program loans were integrated into the
PRGF  policy  matrix  and  included  energy,  judiciary,  civil  service,  agriculture,  trade,  and  capital
market  reform.  An  overview  of  past  and  ongoing  assistance  to  the  sector  is  presented  in
Appendix 3.

D.

Lessons Learned

ADB’s  country  operational  framework  1999-200015  recognizes  the  need  to  sharpen  the
41.
focus of ADB’s operations, taking account of poor portfolio performance, weak governance, and
lack  of  absorptive  capacity  and  counterpart  funds.  Despite  overall  satisfactory  disbursement
levels, which are partly due to tranche releases under program lending, implementation delays
remain  a  major  problem  for  ADB’s  Pakistan  project  portfolio  and  are  being  addressed  through
ongoing dialogue.

42.
Although it is too early to assess the impact of the TEPI Program, a few implementation
delays occurred during the early stages. This was primarily due to a lengthy recruitment process
of  consultants  required  for  institutional  strengthening,  and  complex  interagency  coordination
arrangements. This highlights the need to simplify implementation arrangements even if issues
are  complex  and  the  design  is  comprehensive.  To  systematically  monitor  the  socioeconomic

E.

ADB’s Sector Strategy

45.
ADB’s  medium-term  strategy  for  Pakistan  gives  priority  to  (i)  improving  economic
efficiency  and  export  performance,  (ii)  human  and  social  development,  and  (iii)  governance
and  institutional  strengthening.  In  1997,  support  was  provided  for  reforms  and  expansion  of
domestic capital markets, trade liberalization, export promotion, and private sector-led industrial
growth. In 1999, trade and industry support was provided under the TEPI Program loan.

46. With  poverty  reduction  as  its  overarching  goal,19  ADB  is  preparing  a  poverty  reduction
strategy  for  operations  in  Pakistan.  As  a  first  step,  ADB  will  undertake  a  detailed  poverty
situation  analysis  based  on  existing  information,  to  assess  country  performance  in  achieving
poverty reduction, and review poverty impacts of past ADB assistance. A partnership agreement
between  the  Government  and  ADB  will  then  be  developed  to  set  out  a  long-term  vision  of
poverty reduction, and identify key indicators, institutional milestones, and a specific assistance
plan for the country.

ADB’s  strategy  for  the  financial,  trade,  and  industry  sectors  is  concentrating  on  policy
47.

development of a competitive and diversified financial sector and industrial base in the country.
The policy dialogue is focusing on broadening and deepening financial intermediation, improving
industrial  efficiency  and  competitiveness,  and  continuing  the  trade  liberalization  process.  ADB
will  also  support  industrial  restructuring  with  a  focus  on  encouraging  the  development  of  high-
technology  and  export-oriented 
friendly

F.

Policy Dialogue

49.
Policy  dialogue  has  focused  essentially  on  (i)  overall  reform  of  the  EFS,  (ii)  supporting
the  trade  environment,  and  (iii)  regulatory  issues  to  ensure  the  successful  introduction  of  new
credit enhancement mechanisms.

50. With regard to overall reform of the EFS, dialogue focused on improving the EFS design
and clarity of the circulars. Subsequently the EFS has been extended to indirect and emerging
exporters. More substantive revisions of the EFS scheme, e.g., such as restricting the utilization
of  the  EFS  for  low  value-added  export  or  a  cut  in  EFS  entitlements,  are  being  resisted  by
established exporters as this would erode their easy access to subsidized credit.20 A particular
problem is that no export financing alternatives currently exist; and any adjustment to the EFS
risks disrupting much-needed export growth. In this context, the establishment of an alternative
financing window as a step toward further reform appears to be a sensible approach. The new
facility  should  be  market-based,  easily  accessible,  and  include  benefits  such  as  risk  mitigation
features to encourage migration from the EFS. This complements and supports the agreements
the Government has reached with IMF on phasing out interest rate subsidies and moving to a
market-based rate for the EFS.

51.
Improvements  to  the  overall  trade  environment  are  taken  up  under  the  TEPI  Program,
and include the development of adequate export promotion policies, including free-trade status
schemes such as export processing zones, bonded manufacturing warehouses, or no-duty-no-
drawback schemes; a rationalized tariff regime; and reduction of the statutory rules and orders.
In  June  2000,  the  Government  announced  a  new  trade  policy  including  a  number  of  steps  to
boost exports. Key, however, will be Pakistan’s ability to broaden its export base by offering a
supportive institutional framework and incentive schemes that provide a clear benefit to smaller
and newer exporters to move into the formal economy.

The regulatory treatment of credit enhancement instruments was reviewed to enable the
52.
establishment  and  successful  operation  of  the  PEFG,  and  included  agreement  with  SBP  on  a
low  risk  weighting  by  banks  for  PEFG  guarantees  as  well  as  for  exports  loans  enhanced  with
export  credit  insurance.  This  will  provide  an  additional  incentive  to  the  banking  system  to
actively promote and market these new products.

Given the complex and dynamic nature of the sector, policy dialogue will be continuously

53.
pursued throughout the project implementation period.

IV.

THE PROPOSED PROJECT

A.

Rationale

To reduce poverty and reverse the trend of increasing poverty, Pakistan must achieve a
54.
sustained  annual  per  capita  growth  rate  of  at  least  5  to  6  percent.  Higher  levels  of  economic
growth  will  lead  to  the  creation  of  employment  opportunities  that  are  urgently  needed  to
accommodate  the  1.1  million  workers  who  enter  the  labor  market  annually.  SMEs  tend  to
dominate  labor-intensive  sectors  and  their  growth  can  become  a  major  source  of  employment
provision.  SMEs  also  tend  to  be  more  efficient  than  large-scale  firms  in  certain  sectors.
Importantly, SMEs need to be given a level playing field, including in international markets, so
that they can grow fully and society can reap the benefits from their specialization.

55.
Improving export performance is also key to Pakistan’s macroeconomic stabilization and
economic development. This requires not only increasing sales by existing exporters, but also a
new class of exporters to emerge. To be competitive, Pakistan exporters need access to funding
with conditions similar to those available to international competitors, i.e., at international market
rates, and comparable risk management tools to develop new markets. By improving access to
trade  finance  instruments  in  particular  for  SMEs,  much-needed  capital  for  business  expansion
can be generated internally.

56. While the EFS offers cheap funding to a certain number of established and large volume
exporters,  a  larger  number  of  emerging  exporters  without  access  to  export  finance  are
effectively  excluded  and  must  seek  alternative  financing  at  a  higher  cost,  often  through  the
informal  market.  Many  countries  have  a  dollar  financing  window  as  an  alternative  to  the
domestic  vehicle;  in  theory,  this  window  should  offer  a  lower  interest  rate  if  local  currency  is
deemed to be weaker and depreciating.

Moreover,  adjustments  to  the  financing  system  are  warranted  as  World  Trade
57.
Organization  (WTO)  agreements  call  for  the  removal  of  various  subsidies,  including  trade
finance  related  subsidies.21  Any  reform  and  removal  of  the  distortions  will  -  given  Pakistan’s
political economy and concentrated export structure - be difficult to achieve in the absence of an
alternative financing vehicle.

B.

Objectives and Scope

The overall goal of the Project is to achieve higher and sustainable export-led economic
58.
growth  leading  to  employment  generation.  The  immediate  objectives  are  to  (i)  increase  the
access  of  SMEs  and  emerging  exporters  to  export  credit;  (ii)  offer  greater  choice  of  financing
and  risk  mitigation  instruments  to  exporters,  e.g.,  for  new  product  and  market  development,
competitively priced at international market rates; (iii) support the banking and export community
to  conduct  structured  trade;  and  (iv)  facilitate  reform  of  the  existing  EFS  to  reduce  subsidies.
The Project aims at achieving a considerable leverage of ADB’s financial resources.

Improvements  to  the  existing  export  financing  framework  are  required  to  achieve  these
59.
objectives.  The  Project  will  introduce  three  new  components  into  Pakistan’s  export  financing
system:

                                                
21 

As  a  developing  country,  Pakistan  is  entitled  to  certain  grace  periods  within  which  it  is  to  work  towards  WTO
compliance.  However, once the grace period has expired, Pakistan will be required to fully comply with its WTO
obligations, including removal of export subsidies.

 14

(i) 

(ii) 

establishment of a new dollar based financing facility, the FCEF;

provision  of  a  PRG  for  payment  to  international  confirming  banks  by  Pakistan
issuing banks of L/Cs for imports that are required for export production; and

(iii) 

equity investment in the PEFG.

In  addition,  the  Project  will  facilitate  the  development  and  encourage  the  use  of  credit
60.
enhancement and risk mitigation instruments such as export credit insurance and preshipment
finance guarantees. The Project introduces institutional improvements to export promotion and
administration of the overall export incentive framework.

61.
The  Project  comprises  a  comprehensive  package  for  exporters,  addressing  funding  as
well as risk mitigation issues and leveraging the financial support provided by ADB. The Project
will enable indirect and emerging exporters to access export finance, and support exporters in
venturing  into  new  markets.  A  design  summary  of  the  Project  indicating  target  groups  and
beneficiaries is provided in Appendix 4.

1.

Foreign Currency Export Finance Facility

62.
The FCEF will be a dollar-based refinancing window at SBP that provides an alternative
financing scheme to the EFS. It will be available at market-based terms to direct exporters and
their  suppliers,  i.e.,  indirect  exporters.  It  will  finance  both  domestic  and  imported  inputs  to  be
used  for export production. Financing under the FCEF will be transaction based and require a
firm  export  order  or  export  L/C.  It  will  cover  both  pre-  and  postshipment  requirements  of
exporters. The FCEF be a revolving credit facility for short-term export finance up to 180 days,
aimed at achieving considerable financing leverage over its life.

63.
The FCEF is designed to encourage the use of credit enhancements being developed as
part  of  the  Project,  including  the  PRG  for  import  L/Cs,  preshipment  finance  guarantees  and
export  credit  (postshipment)  insurance.  These  credit  enhancements  will  permit  banks  to  lower
their collateral requirements and free up exporters’ collateral for other financing needs, reduce
the cost of funds for exporters, and minimize payment risks. The FCEF will increase access to
export financing, improve supply-chain financing, and support development of new markets.

The FCEF will be most attractive to (i) emerging and indirect exporters who are largely
64.
excluded  from  the  EFS  and  unable  to  obtain  formal  bank  credit  due  to  the  lack  of  security  to
meet  the  banks’  collateral  requirements,  or  who  reached  their  existing  credit  limits  with  their
banks; (ii) registered importers providing goods for export production; and (iii) common bonded
warehouses.

65.
The FCEF will provide a mechanism for the transition from subsidized EFS financing to
WTO-compliant  export  financing,  and  facilitate  the  Government’s  endeavors  to  move  to  a
sustainable EFS. The FCEF will support a shift within the financial sector to a more transaction-
based financing system, versus the traditional asset-based system. This is a welcome shift that
places greater emphasis on cash-flow analysis, rather than relying on collateral.

The successful introduction of the FCEF depends on an appropriate incentive structure
66.
and  an  easily  implementable  scheme.  In  this  context,  the  process  of  communication  and
consultation  with  stakeholders  to  ensure  acceptability  is  crucial.  Because  FCEF  interest  rates

 15

are likely to be higher than EFS rates,22 the FCEF will be marketed actively with other measures
to enhance its usage and improve the trade finance system.

2.

Partial Risk Guarantee for Import L/C confirmation

67.
As  a  result  of  the  high  country  risk  assigned  to  Pakistan  by  the  international  financial
community, Pakistan banks often encounter difficulties obtaining confirmation of import L/Cs, or
obtain this only at a high cost. This is particularly true for L/Cs with maturity of more than 180
days, or for higher value L/Cs including imports by exporters for plant upgrading, balancing, and
modernization.  International  banks  currently  charge  as  high  as  8  to  10  percent  of  the  value  of
the  import  order  for  confirmation  for  such  L/Cs,  if  confirmation  can  be  obtained  at  all.  Thus,
Pakistan  exporters  who  rely  on  imported  inputs  are  penalized  by  the  negative  country  risk
perception of the international financial community.

68.
By providing a PRG to cover foreign exchange transfer and convertibility risk, the PRG
effectively  transfers  the  Pakistan  country  risk  into  an  ADB  risk.  This  will  enable  international
banks to increase their risk bearing capacity for conducting business with Pakistan, and ensure
the continued willingness of international banks to confirm import L/Cs issued by Pakistan banks
used  for  the  importation  of  goods  and  services  required  for  export  production.  In  particular,
during  periods  of  economic  and  political  uncertainty  the  PRG  will  help  keep  Pakistan  country
exposure  limits  by  international  banks  open  for  continued  confirmation  of  eligible  import  L/Cs.
This will also reduce volatility of confirmation charges for eligible import L/Cs issued by Pakistan
banks.  The  PRG  will  assist  Pakistan  exporters  in  competing  at  similar  terms  as  their
international competitors, without being unduly penalized for Pakistan’s country risk.

69.
The PRG is an integral part of the Project and provides a complementary instrument to
ADB’s  overall  intervention  in  the  export  financing  subsector  in  Pakistan.  The  PRG  will  be
promoted together with and be an enhancement to encourage use of the FCEF. However, the
PRG  will  not  be  restricted  to  the  L/Cs  financed  by  the  FCEF.  While  the  FCEF  addresses  the
short-term  finance  requirements  for  inputs  and  raw  materials  for  exports,  the  PRG  addresses
both short- and medium-term finance requirements for inputs and capital expenditures, such as
spare parts and equipment. This supports export competitiveness and the objectives of the TEPI
Program.

3.

Equity Investment in the PEFG

Export  credit  agencies  (ECAs)  play  an  important  role  in  risk  mitigation  and  export
70.
promotion,  in  particular  in  developing  new  export  markets  and  products.  About  7  percent  of
worldwide  trade,  or  about  $400  billion,  is  supported  annually  by  export  credit  agencies.    More
than  50  countries  have  established  an  export  credit  agency  in  one  form  or  another.  These
include  the  successful  Asian  economies,  including  Hong  Kong,  China;  The  Republic  of  Korea;
Malaysia;  Singapore;  and  Thailand;  as  well  as  Pakistan’s  regional  neighbors  (Egypt,  India,
Jordan, Oman, Sri Lanka, and Turkey). Consultation with industry, banks, and the Government
identified  a  strong  rationale  and  desire  by  the  private  sector  for  the  establishment  of  an  ECA-
type entity in Pakistan. The establishment of PEFG is a significant step in this direction.

                                                
22  Currently,  the  EFS  is  provided  by  SBP  to  commercial  banks  at  a  preferential  rate  of  6  percent  and  onlent  to
exporters at an interest rate of about 8 percent. The FCEF is expected to cost the final borrower about 8.95-9.45
percent (para 77). In discussions with IMF and ADB, the Government agreed to gradually increase the EFS rate
to market rates for Pakistan Rupee financing, currently about 12 percent.

sectors.  In  particular,  the  PEFG  will  issue  bankable  guarantees  to  replace  traditional  collateral
requirements.  Guarantees  will  be  issued  on  behalf  of  new  or  smaller  exporters23  in  favor  of

manufacturing  to  postshipment  finance.  This  will  allow  smaller  or  emerging  export-related
enterprises to get better access to trade-related finance. The PEFG will also seek to enter into a

72.
For  participating  banks,  the  PEFG  offers  a  new  form  of  collateral  with  a  favorable  risk

C. 

Major Terms, Conditions, and Arrangements of the Proposed Loan for the FCEF

1.

Loan Amount and Terms

73.
A loan of $150 million will be provided from ADB’s market-based loan (MBL) window in
US dollars for funding of the FCEF, with maturity of 15 years and grace period of 3 years. The
loan amount is based on import requirements for exports with focus on SMEs and non-traditional
products, and export financing needs to new markets.24 The loan will carry interest at a floating
rate based on the six-month London interbank offer rate (LIBOR) or, at the Government’s option, a
fixed rate based on ADB’s fixed-rate borrowing in dollar terms at the time of disbursement, plus 60
basis points. The Borrower will be given a one-time option to convert the floating rate portion of its
loan  into  a  fixed-rate  loan  or  vice  versa.  The  loan  will    carry  a  1  percent  front-end  fee  and  the
standard commitment charges.

The  MBL  modality  will  be  provided  to  Pakistan  on  an  exceptional  basis25  because:  (i)
74.
although  Pakistan  will  be  the  nominal  Borrower,  the  loan  will  pass  through  SBP  directly  to
financial sector intermediaries on essentially the same MBL terms and conditions (subject to a
small margin to cover SBP’s cost of funds); (ii) this exception is case-specific based on the need
for the FCEF to support short-term financing requirements of privates sector exporters at market
terms;  and  (iii)  by  stating  that  initially  it  will  be  applied  to  selected  borrowers,  the  MBL  policy

                                                
23 

24 

25 

The  PEFG  will  not  issue  guarantees  to  manufacturers  that  use  child  labor  or  are  in  breach  of  Pakistan
environmental regulations.
It is estimated that the import financing requirement is from $375 million for non-traditional exports to $1.7 billion
for all exports. Assuming an average financing period of 120 days, this would require a funding volume of about
$125  million  to  $566  million  (para.  25).  In  addition,  local  inputs  may  be  financed  under  FCEF,  in  particular  for
SMEs  and  for  non-traditional  products.  Should  demand  for  foreign  currency  financing  outstrip  the  FCEF  loan
amount,  the  Government  will  contemplate  additional  alternative  financing  sources  to  complement  FCEF,
including  development  of  an  interbank  market  for  foreign  exchange  to  facilitate  the  use  of  foreign  currency
deposits in Pakistan for short-term trade finance.
ADB’s existing MBL policy contemplates that MBLs will initially only be offered to private sector borrowers and
certain  financial  sector  intermediaries  with  high  priority  needs  for  LIBOR-based  loans  to  manage  their  interest
rate risks. (See R210-94 Revision 1, Final: A Proposal to Introduce a Market-Based Loan Window. 29 November
1994, paras. 4 to 9).

 17

contemplates that, over time, the use of the MBL may be carefully expanded to other borrowers
in appropriate circumstances.

2.

Relending and Onlending Rates

75.
SBP  will  make  the  foreign  exchange  funds  from  the  loan  available  to  participating
commercial banks (PCBs) at a rate equivalent to the Government’s cost of funds including the
60  basis  points  charged  by  ADB,  plus  0.15  percent  to  recover  the  front-end  fee  and  other
administrative charges.26 The onlending rate by PCBs to subborrowers will be determined by the
PCBs  based  on  SBP  guidelines  commensurate  with  the  cost  and  risks  of  subloans,  for  a
maximum maturity of 180 days, with a maximum margin of up to 2 percent per annum.27

Assuming  6-month  LIBOR  at  currently  6.7  percent,  the  base  cost  to  the  PCBs  will  be
76.
7.45 percent, and 8.95  to 9.45 percent to the final borrower. The borrower will also be required
to  pay  the  various  transaction  charges  for  the  risk  mitigation  instruments  associated  with  the
FCEF.  Those  may  include  the  cost  for  (i)  the  PEFG  acquired  to  cover  the  performance  risk  of
the  borrower,  and  (ii)  export  credit  (postshipment)  insurance  to  be  acquired  in  connection  with
the export order.28 With the additional transaction costs related to the credit enhancements, the
total cost of funds to the exporter will be close to the non-EFS cost of funds for local currency,
but will carry reduced risks and collateral requirements; and it will be considerably lower than the
costs incurred by borrowers in the informal sector.

3.

Subloan Size and Period

The  maximum  size  of  any  subloan  to  be  financed  under  the  FCEF  is  $500,000  or
77.
equivalent per transaction, although any individual exporter may have total aggregate drawings
in excess of $500,000 for different export orders for preshipment finances.29 PCBs may finance
up  to  100  percent  of  the  cost,  insurance,  and  freight  (CIF)  or  ex-factory  value  of  the  goods
supplied by the indirect exporter, and up to a maximum of 80 percent of the value of the export
order.  The  maximum  maturity  per  transaction  for  both  direct  and  indirect  exporters  will  be  180
days from the date of drawdown from the FCEF.30 For postshipment finance, a PCB may finance
up  to  100  percent  of  the  export  order  if  payment  is  by  irrevocable  L/C,  or  up  to  80  percent  if
payment is on open account and backed by export credit insurance.

4.

Currency and Foreign Exchange Risk

The  FCEF  will  be  dollar  based  and  self-liquidating,  i.e.,  direct  exporters  with  dollar
78.
receipts have no foreign exchange risk. Any foreign exchange risk for other currency receivables
                                                
26

The  1%  front  end  fee  will  not  be  passed  on  directly  to  the  exporters  but  will  be  allocated  over  the  term  of  the
loan. At  0.15% percent per annum, an average usage of about 50 percent of the FCEF will be required over the
15 year loan period to recover the cost of the front end fee.
The  margin  of  2  percent  is  equal  to  the  maximum  margin  PCBs  can  charge  for  onlending  of  the  EFS.  If
postshipment  financing  is  provided  in  conjunction  with  export  credit  insurance,  the  margin  is  expected  to  be  a
maximum of 1.5 percent.
The PEFG guarantee fee should be a maximum of about 4 percent of the loan, but is expected to be lower for
repeat  clients  and  if  export  credit  insurance  is  available.  The  export  credit  insurance  is  expected  to  average
around 0.5 percent of the value of the export order, but will very much depend on the ultimate credit worthiness
of the offshore buyer and the country risk associated with the country in which the buyer is located.
The maximum loan size for a loan backed by a PEFG guarantee is expected to be $100,000. A maximum loan
size of $500,000 is being suggested here in the event that larger direct exporters who would not require a PEFG
guarantee wish to access the FCEF.
The date of drawdown will the date on which funds from the FCEF are committed to the PCB.

5.

Eligibility Criteria for PCBs and Subborrowers

79.
To  participate  in  the  FCEF,  a  PCB  must  meet  minimum  paid-up  capital  and  capital
adequacy ratios, as well as income recognition and provisioning standards in the SBP prudential
regulations.  All  banks  meeting  the  eligibility  criteria  will  be  permitted  to  draw  on  the  FCEF,
without  restriction  by  their  balance  sheet  size.31  This  should  assist  in  particular  the  medium-
sized trade finance banks for which export finance demand outstrips EFS supply.

80.
The FCEF will be available to eligible direct and indirect exporters (as defined in the Duty
and  Tax  Remission  for  Export  Rules,  2000).  To  be  eligible,  the  exporter  must  (i)  have  a  firm
export  order  (or,  in  the  case  of  an  indirect  exporter,  a  firm  supply  order  linked  to  an  export
order);  (ii)  be  registered  with  the  EPB;  (iii)  not  have  any  outstanding  nonperforming  loans  to
financial  institutions,  (iv)  be  in  compliance  with  the  country’s  current  environmental  and  labor
laws and regulations, including the Employment of Children Act, 1991, as amended from time to
time, and (v) not have received for an FCEF-financed export order funding for good or services
from EFS (part I or II) or any other source.32  Large and established direct exporters of traditional
products who do not fall into the SME category33 cannot, in the aggregate, access more than 50
percent of the FECF at any given time.34

6.

Executing Agency and Implementation Arrangements

The Executing Agency for the FCEF will be SBP.  SBP has been operating the EFS and
81.
has  considerable  experience  with  the  administration  of  export  refinancing  facilities.  SBP  has
also been the beneficiary of institutional strengthening TA by the World Bank, and has recently
upgraded  its  policies,  procedures,  data  processing,  and  administrative  capabilities.  It  has  a
number  of  competent  staff,  many  of  who  were  recently  recruited  from  the  private  sector  at
market-based salaries.

82.
SBP  has  set  up  an  apex  unit  under  overall  responsibility  of  the  Executive  Director  for
Banking  Supervision  to  administer  the  FCEF,  and  which  will  open  and  maintain  a  special
account  for  the  FCEF.  Funds  from  the  FCEF  will  be  made  available  to  qualified  exporters
through PCBs, which will draw on the FCEF on a subborrower’s application for export finance on
a first-come, first-served basis. The PCBs will process the export financing documentation with

Depending on demand and the utilization pattern for the FCEF, the use of the FCEF by non-SME exporters may

83.
To  promote  the  FCEF  and  other  trade  finance  vehicles,  including  the  PRG  and  PEFG,
several  other  export-related  agencies  will  be  involved,  including  the  EPB,  industry  and  trade
