7.

Implementation Schedule

84.
The FCEF will be made available for at least 15 years, starting from loan effectiveness.
The Government has assured ADB that the FCEF will be continued for as long as it is required
to  ensure  equitable  and  easy  access  to  credit  at  world  market  rates  for  foreign  currency  for
exporters, and SMEs in particular.

8.

Disbursements

85.
Prior  to  loan  effectiveness,  SBP  will  establish  an  FCEF  special  account  in  accordance
with arrangements agreed to with ADB for disbursement of the loan proceeds. ADB will advance
funds to the special account, on which the PCBs will draw based on the subloan applications of
their clients. The special account will be a revolving credit facility which will be replenished upon
maturity and repayment of the subloans.

86.
The loan will be disbursed to the special account in three disbursements based upon the
use of the facility. The first disbursement of $30 million will be released upon loan effectiveness.
Two  subsequent  disbursements  of  up  to  $60  million  each  will  be  released  upon  80  percent
usage of the preceding disbursements, based on a withdrawal application by SBP and subject
satisfactory  implementation  performance  as  well  as  anticipated  future  demand  for  the  FCEF.
SPB will advise ADB of the expected withdrawal date for the next disbursement when the FCEF
has  reached  70  percent  usage.  The  withdrawal  application  by  SBP  will  be  accompanied  by
supporting documents to demonstrate the use of the FCEF facility in accordance with the terms
of the Loan Agreement, and include a statement of outstanding sub-loans under FCEF.

87.
Any amount not disbursed by ADB within three years will be canceled. The Government
assured  to  maintain  at  least  80  percent  utilization,  on  average,  of  the  outstanding  FCEF  loan
amount  after  loan  closing  date,  or  take  measures  as  agreed  with  ADB,  including  partial
prepayment of the FCEF loan.

88.
The  liquidity  built  up  within  the  special  account  will  be  used  solely  for  onlending  to
eligible subborrowers in accordance with the Loan Agreement for the FCEF.  Disbursement of
FCEF  funds  to  subborrowers  will  be  in  line  with  the  FCEF  regulations  prepared  by  SBP  and
agreed  with  ADB.  Procedures  for  processing  FCEF  applications  are  outlined  in  more  detail  in
Appendix 5.

9.

Procurement

89.
The  FCEF  will  be  available  for  imported  inputs  from  ADB  member  countries  and  for
domestic  inputs  to  be  utilized  for  exports  against  foreign-currency  denominated  export  orders,
export L/Cs, or such other customary export documentation applicable to a particular trade (as
may  be  permitted  under  the  FCEF  regulations).  Certain  inputs  will  not  be  eligible  for  FCEF
financing, such as weapons, ammunition, nuclear materials, and other items to be agreed to by

 20

ADB  and  SBP  as  part  of  a  negative  list.  SBP,  through  the  PCBs,  will  require  subborrowers  to
demonstrate that the inputs being financed from the FCEF proceeds will have their origin in an
ADB member country, and that procurement procedures in accordance with normal commercial
practices,  as  appropriate  under  the  circumstances,  have  been  applied.  SBP  will  provide
certificates concerning procurement as ADB reasonably requires.

90.
The  subborrower  will  be  required  to  confirm  in  its  FCEF  application  that  it  has  not
received financing for the export order under any other export finance scheme, including part II
of EFS.  SBP and PCBs will need to cooperate and documentation will be designed to minimize
the possibility of duplicate financing of any export order.

10.

Accounts and Audit

91.
SBP  will  establish  and  maintain  separate  accounts  for  the  FCEF  in  accordance  with
accounting procedures acceptable to ADB. This will be audited annually by independent auditors
in  accordance  with  auditing  standards  acceptable  to  ADB.  Certified  copies  of  the  audited
accounts  and  financial  statements  and  the  report  of  the  auditors  will  be  submitted  to  ADB  in
English within 12 months after the end of each fiscal year.

92.
SBP will register transaction details upon approval of each request for FCEF refinancing
and  monitor  utilization  of  the  FCEF.  SBP  will  also  require  that  each  PCB  maintains  adequate
legal documentation and records on the use of the loan and subloan proceeds in accordance with
the  standards  of  a  prudent  lender.    SBP  will  enable  inspection  of  the  PCBs  and  relevant
subborrowers records and documents for the FCEF as required.

11.

Reports and Reviews

93.
SBP  will  provide  ADB  with  quarterly  progress  reports  on  FCEF  utilization  including
information on (i) number of transactions and participating banks, (ii) lending terms and conditions
to the commercial banks and subborrowers, (iii) utilization of funds for imports (including country
of  origin  and  products)  and  exports  (country  of  destination  and  product),  and  (iv)  any  other
matters relating to the loan purposes as requested by ADB.

94.
Prior  to  the  release  of  the  second  disbursement  of  the  FCEF  loan,  or  at  any  time
considered  appropriate,  ADB  and  the  Government  will  jointly  review  implementation  of  the
FCEF.  If  FECF  utilization  does  not  meet  expectations,  ADB  and  the  Government  will  consider
measures to enhance operation of the FCEF facility.  Such measures may include: (i) phasing
out financing of imported inputs under the EFS, (ii) lowering the interest rate differential between
the FCEF facility and the EFS, (iii) altering the implementation arrangements so that the FCEF
facility  is  administered  directly  by  one  or  more  of  the  PCBs,  (iv)  entering  into  subsidiary  loan
agreements  with  one  or  more  of  the  PCBs  for  onlending  to  subborrowers,  or  (v)  such  other
measures  as  may  be  considered  appropriate.    Following  release  of  the  second  disbursement,
review  missions  will  monitor  the  FCEF  at  least  annually,  to  follow  up  on  the  periodic  progress
reports.

95.
A comprehensive midterm review will be undertaken 18 months after project inception to
review all aspects of implementation. This review will focus on (i) SBP performance; (ii) progress
in  disbursement  and  adequacy  of  implementation  arrangements,  including  the  compliance  with
exporter’s  eligibility  criteria,  collection,  and  arrears  performance;  (iii)  policy  constraints  in
implementation; and (iv) initial impact.

 21

Within three months of the FCEF loan closing date, SBP will prepare and furnish to ADB

96.
a completion report.

D.

Major Terms, Conditions, and Arrangements of the Proposed PRG Facility

1.

Guarantee Amount and Terms

97.
ADB  will  provide  a  PRG  up  to  a  total  outstanding  amount  of  $150  million  to  guarantee
payment  to  international  banks  that  are  confirming  eligible  import  L/Cs  issued  by  Pakistan
banks, if the payment obligation under the L/C is not made as a result of a covered risk. ADB’s
guarantee will be backed by a Government counterguarantee and indemnity.

The  PRG  will  be  of  a  revolving  nature  and  new  L/Cs  may  be  covered  to  replace  the
98.
liabilities of L/Cs that have matured. This will leverage a significant volume of imports required
for export production. The guarantee limit is based on estimated confirmation needs of imported
inputs into export production, including raw materials as well as machinery for plant upgrading
and modernization.35 The actual utilization of PRG is expected to fluctuate in line with changing
country  risk  perception  and  corresponding  change  in  risk  premia  and  confirmation  lines  by
international confirming banks. Near full utilization of this limit is anticipated to occur only during
periods of political and economic uncertainty; actual utilization will likely be much less than the
limit  during  periods  of  political  and  economic  stability,  and  during  such  times  be  primarily  for
medium term L/Cs with maturity over 180 days and a maximum term of up to three years.36

99.
To avail of the PRG, ADB will charge the Government a front-end fee up to 0.30 percent
payable on the maximum nominal amount of the PRG. 37 ADB will also charge the Government,
through a facility agent, a PRG guarantee fee of 0.4 percent per annum on the aggregate value
of the maximum liability of all L/Cs covered, i.e., outstanding, under the PRG from time to time,
calculated on a daily basis and payable quarterly. The Government may recoup these fees from
the guarantee fee charged to the final beneficiaries.

2.

Implementation Schedule

The PRG will be available for a maximum of six years from the effective date. After the
100.
third  year  from  the  effective  date,  no  new  guarantees  will  be  issued,  unless  agreed  otherwise
between ADB and the Government. The facility agent will ensure that the term of all L/Cs to be
covered mature under no circumstances later than the PRG’s expiration date. The availability of
the PRG, to the extent it is uncommitted, may be canceled at the end of the third year if after
consultation with the Government the PRG is determined to no longer be required.

                                                
35 

36 

37

See para 25, footnote 24, and Appendix 2 for imported inputs into export production and import structure. It is
estimated that currently about 20 percent of Pakistan’s imports require confirmation, although this may be less
for L/Cs below  90 days and more for longer term L/Cs.
The PRG will be neutral on ADB’s lending headroom as compared to OCR lending, although significant leverage
of the PRG is expected through its revolving nature. The guaranteed limit amount signifies the maximum ADB
exposure,  as  only  the  face  value  of  the  L/Cs  but  no  explicit  interest  is  covered.  The  counterguarantee  by  the
Government  also  gives  ADB  the  right  to  withhold  disbursements  for  other  committed  loans  to  Pakistan  should
the Government fail to honor its obligations.
The  actual  front-end  fee  will  be  calculated  in  line  with  ADB’s  guarantee  policy  and  depend  on  a  number  of
factors,  including,  among  other:  (i)  the  calculation  of  “loan  equivalence”;  and  (ii)  whether  the  Facility  is  made
available in steps (or tranches), or in total.

 22

3.

Risks Covered and Counterguarantee

101.
The  PRG  will  be  backed  by  ADB’s  ordinary  capital  resources.  The  PRG  will  guarantee
100  percent  of  the  face  value  of  each  L/C,  provided  that  failure  to  pay  under  the  L/C  by  the
issuing  bank  is  caused  by  foreign  exchange  inconvertibility  or  transferability  blockage,  or  any
other non-commercial risk agreed upon.

102.
In no event will the PRG guarantee, indemnify, or cover guaranteed banks (GBs) for any
other  risks  associated  with  performance  of  the  issuing  banks,  nor  any  underlying  disputes  or
defaults between the supplier and importer or importer and the issuing banks. The Government
will fully counterguarantee and indemnify ADB for any amount paid under the PRG as a result of
demand made by a GB.

103. Should the Government be required to pay any amount under the counterguarantee, but
is unable to do so, ADB may, at its sole discretion

(i) declare  default  by  the  Government  under  the  PRG  and  thus  a  cross  default  under

other ADB loans to the Government, including the FCEF,

(ii)

treat  the  unpaid  amount  as  an  emergency  loan  with  terms  and  conditions
appropriate for such a loan, or

(iii) take other action that it is empowered to take.

4.

Guarantee Arrangements

104.
To implement the PRG, ADB will appoint a facility agent who will enter into a master risk
participation agreement (MRPA), or similar agreement with each GB. The facility agent will act
as an agent between ADB, the Government and the GBs to administer, promote, and market the
PRG in Pakistan and internationally. The guarantee mechanism is illustrated in Appendix 6.

105. Master Risk Participation Agreements. Details of the guarantee in favor of the GB will
be  captured  in  an  MRPA  (or  similar  instrument)  to  be  concluded  between  the  GB,  the  facility
agent,  and  possibly  ADB.  Each  MRPA  will  specify  the  guaranteed  risks,  how  demand  can  be
made  on  ADB  if  a  payment  is  not  made  under  a  covered  L/C,  and  how  subrogation  will  be
arranged,  among  other  things.  To  the  extent  possible,  the  MRPA  documents  will  be  based  on
industry standard MRPAs commonly used within the trade finance and export credit industries,
or contracts of cover used by the political risk insurance industry.

106.
Information requirements imposed on the GB that will be specified in each MRPA include
(i) notification of proposed risk participation,38 which will be sent by the GB to the facility agent
seeking approval for cover; (ii) notification of risk participation, which will be sent by the GB to
the facility agent no later than the day on which the GB incurs risks under the eligible L/C and
will confirm all the details previously provided; and (iii) quarterly statements summarizing ADB’s
exposure (and ultimately the Government’s) liability under the PRG facility.

107.
Facility Agent. ADB will appoint an international commercial bank, insurance company
or other highly trustworthy party with extensive relevant experience to be the facility agent. The
facility agent will (i) arrange and manage the several MRPAs, entered into from time to time with
various GBs; (ii) receive all notifications issued by GBs; (iii) collect all guarantee fees from the
                                                
38 

This notification will specify the name of the issuing bank, L/C amount, term, description of imports, and only a
few other pertinent facts

 23

GBs; (iv) receive any demand made by the GBs under an MRPA, which will be immediately sent
to  ADB  and  the  Government;  (v)  provide  quarterly  statements  showing  ADB’s  and  the
Government’s liability under each MRPA and the PRG; (vi) effectively administer the PRG; and
(vii) do other things required to administer and promote the PRG facility. The facility agent will be
selected following transparent selection procedures.

108.
The facility agent, in some respects, acts in a similar manner to an executing agency, but
will  have  broader  responsibilities  that  must  be  undertaken  independent  of  any  Government
influence.  The  PEFG  may  be  suited  to  take  over  some  of  the  duties  of  the  facility  agent  in
Pakistan  once  it  has  become  fully  operational  and  acquired  the  necessary  management  and
trade finance expertise, information technology, and back office. As the PEFG has a central role
in  the  export  cycle,  it  will  have  the  ability  to  link  imports  supported  by  the  L/Cs  to  the  ultimate
export.

109.
To  make  best  use  the  PRG,  ideally,  the  importer  and  L/C  issuing  bank  will  explore
access  to  the  PRG  before  the  start  of  negotiations  for  a  new  supply  contract  between  the
importer  and  international  supplier.  This  will  ensure  that  the  PRG  benefits  are  adequately
reflected in the pricing of the supply (importation) contract which normally takes account of L/C
confirmation  charges.  Access  to  the  PRG  can  also  be  at  the  request  of  the  international
suppliers’ confirming banks.

5.

Pricing for Users

110.
The facility agent will charge each GB a guarantee fee as a percent per annum, which
will be payable by the GB to the facility agent at the time of confirmation for each L/C. The fee
will be determined through discussion with the potential facility agent, potential GBs, and issuing
banks  prior  to  the  PRG  becoming  available.  The  guarantee  fee  may  be  changed  from  time  to
time thereafter to reflect market conditions. The fee will be established at a level that that will be
high enough to discourage use of the PRG for sight L/Cs or 90 day or less term L/Cs (which for
the time being are understood to be easily confirmed), while attractive to both L/C-issuing banks
and confirming banks for 180-day plus term L/Cs. The GB is expected to pass the benefit of the
PRG cover on to the supplier and ultimately to the Pakistan exporter and importer by reducing
confirmation costs (para 109).

111.
The facility agent will be responsible for collecting the guarantee fee from each GB and
will  deposit  that  amount  into  a  bank  account.39  This  account  will  be  used  to  pay  (i)  first,  the
facility agent’s administration fee (which will be negotiated); (ii) then ADB’s PRG guarantee fee;
(iii) then the Government’s guarantee fee; and (iv) the cost incurred by the PEFG and or other
parties,  mutually  agreed  to  by  ADB  and  the  Government,  to  carry  on  agreed  marketing  and
promotional activities to increase knowledge and use of effective trade finance and the programs
supported by the TEPI Program.

6.

Eligible L/Cs

112.

The PRG, through each MRPA, will only guarantee L/Cs that

(i)

conform  to  the  Uniform  Customary  Practices,  International  Chamber  of  Commerce
publication 500 (UCP 500), and are irrevocable and unconditional obligations to pay;

(ii)  have terms of up to 360 days, but may on a case-by-case basis be up to three years;

                                                
39 

The account will in effect be an offshore escrow account.

 24

(iii)  are issued for goods, services, spare parts, or capital equipment to be imported from

ADB member countries to support export production;

(iv)  have  a  face  value  of  no  less  than  $5,000  and  no  more  than  $1,000,000,  but  on  a

case-by-case basis could be up to $2,000,000;

(v)  are  issued  by  a  registered  Pakistan  bank  that  complies  with  SBP  prudential

regulations; and

(vi)  are issued for goods, services, spare parts, or capital equipment to be imported from
ADB  member  countries  to  support  export  promotion,  or  imported  inputs  to  be
financed  under  the  FCEF,  or  linked  to  the  TEPI-related  schemes  such  as  the
proposed duty and tax revision for exports rules, common bonded warehouse rules,
and PEFG guarantee.

113. While confirmation of L/Cs of less than 90-day maturity has become a lesser issue over
the past six months, confirmation problems and high cost continue to be encountered for longer
term L/Cs, in particular over 180 days. This is a particular problem for the import of spare parts
and  capital  equipment  for  plant  upgrading  and  modernization  by  exporters.  However,  the
effectiveness of the proposed PRG facility for longer maturities will ultimately depend on whether
Pakistan banks are willing and able to provide credit for more than 360 days.

114.
L/Cs  that  are  not  eligible  for  cover  under  the  PRG  will  include  those  used  for  the
importation of (i) arms, ammunition, and other military materials; (ii) radioactive and associated
materials, nuclear reactors, and fuel elements (cartridges) nonirradiated for nuclear reactors; (iii)
consumer and luxury goods; or (iv) other imports specified in advance by the Government.

7.

Monitoring and Reporting

The facility agent will provide quarterly statements showing ADB’s and the Government’s
115.
liability under each MRPA, the PRG, and the counterguarantee and indemnity, as well as other
information from time to time regarding overall PRG operation, what imports are supported, and
how they are ultimately used in export production.

E.

Major Terms, Conditions, and Arrangements of the Proposed Equity Investment in
PEFG

1.

Investment Amount and Shareholding Structure

117. ADB will subscribe for 20 percent of the issued and paid-up capital of the PEFG, for an
investment  of  up  to  $2  million  equivalent.  The  PEFG  will  be  established  as  an  unlisted  public
limited  company  under  the  Pakistan  Companies  Ordinance,  1984.  It  will  be  a  self-sustaining,
independently managed entity with initial equity capitalization from the Pakistan banking sector.
The  subscribed  PEFG  equity  is  expected  to  be  $10  million  equivalent  in  Pakistan  rupees.
However,  the  initial  paid-in  capitalization  will  be  about  $2  million  and  ADB’s  initial  subscription
will  be  for  up  to  $400,000  equivalent.  The  timing  of  subsequent  closings  to  achieve  the  full
capitalization  of  $10  million  equivalent  will  depend  upon  the  volume  of  demand  for  PEFG’s
products and a decision of its board of directors. The full investment is expected to be paid-up
within  three  years  from  the  start  of  operation  of  PEFG  and  will  permit  an  annual  guarantee
volume of up to $100 million to SMEs for export finance (para. 130).

 25

The Pakistan private sector commercial banks, led by the New Private Scheduled Banks
118.
in  Pakistan  (NPSBP)  are  the  core  investors40  and  will  form  the  sponsor  group  of  the  PEFG,
taking  up  about  50  percent  of  the  equity.  These  banks  have  well  established  ties  with  the
domestic industrial sector, including with mid-sized and smaller companies, and are particularly
active in trade finance. In addition, two nationalized commercial banks, Habib Bank and National
Bank of Pakistan, will take an equity stake of about 20 percent in PEFG. Toward this end, the
sponsor  banks  and  nationalized  commercial  banks  have  in  November  2000  negotiated  a  draft
Share  Subscription  and  Shareholders  Agreement.  Other  international  financial  institutions,
including the IFC, have been approached and are considering an investment in PEFG.

119. Although  ADB  will  initially  be  the  single  largest  shareholder,  NPSBP  will  act  as  a
cohesive sponsor group and will take the lead in PEFG management. NPSBP will appoint, as a
group, a controlling block of directors. The directors will appoint one bank within the group, on a
rotating  basis,  to  be  the  point  of  contact  or  agent  for  all  the  other  banks  in  the  group.  The
documentation  will  clearly  indicate  that  even  though  ADB  is  the  single  largest  individual
shareholder, it will not be in a controlling position. ADB will be represented on the PEFG board
for the primary purpose of monitoring its investment and to ensure the company is operated in
accordance with its memorandum and articles, as well as to ensure coordination with the trade
policies promoted under the TEPI Program.

The  PEFG  is  scheduled  for  incorporation  prior  to  31  December  2000.41  The  PEFG  is
120.
expected  to  be  listed  on  the  stock  exchange  within  5  years  of  initial  operation,  and  ADB  may
divest  its  shares  thereafter.  Ordinary  shares  will  carry  preemptive  rights  to  enable  the  initial
sponsors to maintain control of shareholding in the early years.

2.

Basic Business Principles

121. Export trade finance guarantee certificates, issued by the PEFG, will act as a substitute
for traditional repayment collateral or other forms of borrowers’ pledge. Such collateral or pledge
is typically required by financial institutions in Pakistan as a condition for providing preshipment
export trade credit to an exporter or an indirect exporter.

The PEFG will guarantee up to 80 percent of an exporter’s performance risk, leaving 20
122.
percent  with  the  exporter’s  banks.  The  PEFG  will  follow  a  vigorous  credit-scoring  system
modeled  on  best  practices,  and  hire  management  and  credit  analysts  that  understand  trade
finance  and  associated  customer  needs.  The  PEFG  will  look  at  evidence  that  exporters  are
genuine with creditworthy off-shore buyers, trading on an L/C, or a bona-fide export contract for
trade  on  open  account.  This  is  critical  given  the  experience  of  other  preshipment  export  credit
agencies around the world.

123. As a general principle, the PEFG will seek to secure one half of the guarantee it extends,
with a flexible range of repayment security types. This is significantly less than the level financial
institutions currently require within Pakistan, especially for SMEs.

                                                
40  NPSBP  includes:  Askari  Commercial  Bank;  Bank  Alfalah;  Bank  Al  Habib;  Gulf  Commercial  Bank;  Metropolitan
Bank;  Platinum  Commercial  Bank;  Prime  Commercial  Bank;  Prudential  Commercial  Bank;  Soneri  Bank;  and
Union Bank. In addition, Habib Bank AG Zurich will join as core investor from the domestic private sector banks.
The  Memorandum  and  Articles  of  Association  of  PEFG  have  been  drafted  and  will  be  filed  with  the  Securities
and  Exchange  Commission  of  Pakistan  (SECP)  after  formal  commitment  from  ADB  is  received.  SECP  has
confirmed the availability of the name for PEFG.

41 

 26

To  be  attractive  to  the  banking  community,  PEFG  guarantees  will  carry  a  low-risk
124.
weighting  under  the  SPB  prudential  regulations  for  commercial  banks.  The  Government  has
given its assurance that low-risk rating to be agreed with SBP and acceptable to ADB and other
shareholders will be allocated to the PEFG guarantees.

125.
The PEFG will operate as a corporate body and be subject to disclosure of information
and  regulation  by  the  Corporate  Law  Wing  of  the  Securities  and  Exchange  Commission  of
Pakistan (SECP), as is any other company incorporated under the Companies Ordinance, 1984.
The PEFG will also seek a credit rating from an established rating agency in Pakistan.42

126.
The  PEFG  will  play  an  important  role  in  supporting  the  entire  trade  cycle,  directly  and
indirectly.  The  PEFG  will  act  as  conduit  for  the  provision  of  export  credit  insurance  to  protect
exporters  from  international  buyer  default.  Toward  this  end,  PEFG  will  seek  strategic  alliances
with international credit insurance providers and export credit agencies. Once fully operational,
the PEFG may also act as the agent for the proposed PRG. The PEFG will thus play a critical
role  in  linking  the  pre-  and  postshipment  stages  of  the  financing  cycle  and  administering  the
credit enhancement facilities.

3.

Staffing and Organization

The  PEFG  is  expected  to  have  25  staff.  This  should  provide  the  human  resource
127.
capacity and depth to handle up to 2,000 transactions per year, and is in line with staffing levels
at local branches of multinational banks for trade activities in Pakistan. Recognizing the critical
importance  of  having  high  quality,  experienced  senior  management  and  staff,  staff  will  be
carefully recruited from the private sector at competitive market salaries. Initial staffing may be
supported through secondments from banks participating as PEFG shareholders. The PEFG will
maintain a vigorous program of skills upgrading, including distance learning where appropriate.
An organzational plan is presented in Appendix 7.

128.
The  PEFG  will  be  headquartered  in  Karachi,  and  rely  heavily  on  IT  to  automate  its
processes  and  risk  assessment,  to  leverage  the  small  number  of  professional  staff.  It  will  also
allow submission of online applications. PEFG staff will travel extensively to promote the PEFG
and  carry  out  risk  assessments.  The  use  of  pattern  recognition  software  and  a  computerized
expert system for preliminary transaction review scoring will ensure relevant administrative scale
economies.

The corporate structure will comprise a board of about 10 directors.  Board members will
129.
be appointed pro rata based on shareholding. ADB will reserve the right to nominate at least one
board  member.  NPBSP  will  jointly  nominate  up  to  5  directors  to  the  board.  A  policy  advisory
committee will be set up, with representation from the Government (Ministry of Commerce, EPB,
and  Ministry  of  Finance),  and  from  exporters’  associations,  and  industry  representatives  to
institutionalize the policy dialogue with the Government and private sector representatives. The
corporate structure is described in Table 1.

4.

Business Projections

130. Business  is  expected  to  reach  $100  million  per  annum  in  guarantee  volume—about  1
percent  of  Pakistan’s  exports—within  the  three  to  four  years.  This  compares  with  about  7
percent of trade that is guaranteed on average worldwide.  This volume can be supported by a
capital  base  of  $10  million  and  gearing  of  5:1  with  a  twice  yearly  turnover,  i.e.,  an  average
guarantee  term  of  180  days.  The  projected  volume  amounts  to  about  2,500  transactions  per
year  at  an  average  volume  of  $40,000,  compared  with  about  32,000  transactions  handled  by
SBP annually.

5.

Guarantee Fee Pricing

131.
The PEFG will operate on a commercial and sustainable basis charging a guarantee fee
to cover cost and return to shareholders. Pricing of guarantee products and related services will
be  central  to  PEFG’s  success.  This  will  require  an  ongoing  assessment  of  current  revenues,
potential market, demand sensitivities, and potential follow-on business. Pricing will differentiate
by  the  exporter  risk  profile  and  be  in  line  with  what  other  preshipment  credit  providers  with  a
similar mandate to the PEFG charge internationally.

132.
The  PEFG  must  be  in  a  financially  sound  position,  i.e.,  actuarially  self-sustaining,  to
permit itself to promptly pay, in full, any and all repayment guarantee claims, once submitted by
customers  with  accompanying  documentation  and  proof.    Indeed,  ability  to  promptly  and  fully
meet claims obligations, paralleled by the ability to pursue recoveries to the full extent of the law
in  Pakistan  and,  on  a  case-by-case,  internationally,  will  be  critical  to  recognition  in  the
marketplace of the PEFG as a viable institution.

133.
The  PEFG  will  also  levy  a  0.25  percent  fee,  per  transaction,  with  an  initial  maximum
charge of PRs10,000, to defray administrative overhead. Administrative fees for whole turnover
guarantees  will  be  determined  case-by-case,  with  a  lower  fee  for  guarantees  involving  simple
repeat  orders  that  are  L/C-based  and  a  higher  fee  for  guarantees  where  exports  are  open
account and document against acceptance (DA).

6.

Financial Plans and Principles and Strategy

134.
The  PEFG  will  have  a  sound  balance  sheet  and  sufficient  reserves.  It  is  expected  to
break  even  on  its  operational  activities  within  three  to  four  years,  and  be  floated  on  the  stock
exchange within 5 years. ADB will divest its shares thereafter.

135. Other than business volume, the critical variables for financial viability are fees charged
and claim loss ratio. Considering the experiences of other countries, the indications that PEFG

 28

will  be  profitable  are  very  strong.  Various  sensitivity  scenarios  and  financial  analysis  are  in
Appendix 8.

136. Appreciation of and sensitivity to the needs of target sectors will allow the PEFG to build
the kind of business volume necessary to ensure an adequate fee income versus claims ratio. In
general,  PEFG  will  follow  the  principle  of  the  law  of  large  numbers  and  portfolio  diversity,  to
ensure that actuarial soundness is maintained.

7.

Accounts, Audit and Reporting

137.
The  PEFG  will  establish  annual  accounts  in  accordance  with  international  accounting
standards,  consistently  applied.  PEFG’s  financial  statements  will  be  audited  annually  by  an
internationally recognized accounting firm appointed by the board of directors. Certified copies of
the  audited  accounts  and  financial  statements  will  be  submitted  to  the  shareholders  annually,
within three months of each fiscal year end.

8.

Legal Documentation

138. ADB  and  other  shareholders  will  enter  into  appropriate  subscription  and  shareholders’
agreements whereby ADB will commit to subscribe up to the equivalent of $2 million in ordinary
PEFG  shares.  The  shareholders  agreement  will  confirm  that  the  NPSBP  will  act  as  a  sponsor
group and that ADB will not play a significant role in the management or strategic direction of the
company  despite  it  being  initially  the  single  largest  individual  shareholder.  The  agreements  on
terms  and  conditions  satisfactory  to  ADB  will  be  entered  into  following  approval  of  the  PEFG
investment by ADB’s Board of Directors.

139. ADB will also satisfy itself with the terms and conditions of the constituent documents of
the PEFG.

F.

Technical Assistance

140.
The TA will develop the institutional capacities of the EPB so that it can play an effective
role  in  trade  facilitation  and  export  promotion.  The  TA  will  assist  in  restructuring  and
development  of  EPB,  to  effectively  interface  with  private  sector  trade  and  export  associations,
international  partners,  and  individual  exporters,  to  promote  utilization  of  the  various  export
incentive schemes and facilities available, and to support the development of new markets.

141.
The  TA  will  be  funded  on  a  grant  basis  not  exceeding  $800,000  equivalent  from  the
ADB-funded  TA  program,  to  cover  the  entire  foreign  exchange  cost  and  part  of  the  local
currency  cost.  The  TA  will  comprise  two  components,  using  the  cluster  modality.  The  first
component will be a small-scale TA review of EPB’s strategic plan and operational priorities, and
is expected to begin within the first quarter of 2001 and be implemented within two months. The
second  component  will  undertake  EPB  capacity  building  activities,  with  focus  on  management
information system and training needs. It is expected to begin by June 2001, to be implemented
over  9  months.  A  total  of  about  18  person-months  of  international  consulting  services  and
27person-months  of  domestic  consulting  services  will  be  required.  The  details  for  the  capacity
building aspects under the second component will be finalized subject to the findings of the first
component.  Consultants  will  be  recruited  in  accordance  with  ADB’s  Guidelines on the Use of
Consultants  and  other  arrangements  satisfactory  to  ADB  for  the  engagement  of  domestic
consultants. Details on the TA and outline terms of reference are in Appendix 9.

 G.

Benefit Monitoring and Evaluation

29

142. Benefit monitoring and evaluation of the social and poverty impact of the TEPI Program
is  being  carried  out  under  TA  3183-PAK  (footnote  16).  The  Ministry  of  Finance  and  a  well-
respected  research  organization,  the  Pakistan  Institute  of  Development  Economics,  are
implementing this TA. Under this TA a framework was developed for consultations to take place
with key stakeholders during implementation of the TEPI program. This will also take account of
the measures promoted under the Project. Measures potentially available to affected groups will
be  reviewed  and  monitoring  of  the  positive  and  adverse  social  impact,  as  well  as  the
effectiveness of social safety nets, coping mechanisms, and mitigation measures is ongoing.  A
comprehensive  evaluation  of  the  TEPI  Program’s  poverty  impact  will  also  take  place.    As  this
exercise already includes employment growth in the SME sector, the TA results will be directly
relevant to determining the impact of the Project.

H.

Environmental and Social Measures and Impact

The  Project  will  have  no  direct  environmental  impact  and  no  mitigating  measures  are
143.
required.  Longer-term  environmental  impacts  will  result  from  a  general  increase  in  living
standards  and  decreased  urbanization.  Detailed  environmental  and  social  assessment  were
carried out under the TEPI Program. In addition, a social and poverty assessment for the Project
is in Appendix 10. The main impact on the poor and on other vulnerable groups during project
implementation will be the creation of additional employment opportunities.

144.
Traditionally,  the  SME  sector  in  Pakistan  is  known  for  not  adhering  to  internationally
recognized labor standards, especially for child labor and female workers. However, efforts are
being made by the Government with support by the assistance or development community, as
well as under increasing commercial pressure, to address these issues in a number of export-
oriented  industries  such  as  carpet-weaving,  sporting  goods,  and  surgical  instruments.  In
addition, exporters will be required to certify that they are in compliance with Pakistan labor laws
in order to be eligible for financing from the FCEF.

V.

PROJECT JUSTIFICATION

A.

Economic and Financial Analysis

145.
The  Project  will  increase  access  to  credit  and  reduce  the  financing  cost  of  SMEs  and
emerging exporters that have so far been excluded from the export finance system. The Project
will  also  offer  risk  mitigation  measures,  and  the  provision  of  postshipment  insurance  to  be
promoted under the Project will assist exporters to enter new markets. This will increase exports,
generate  employment,  and  increase  foreign  exchange  earnings.  The  improved  balance  of
payments  position  will  contribute  to  macroeconomic  stabilization.  The  Project  will  support  the
reform of the subsidized EFS and prepare Pakistan to comply with long-term WTO obligations.

146. Accomplishing an actual increase in exports and utilization of the FCEF, as well as the
other  products,  is  a  function  of  a  number  of  variables.  The  loan  amount  provided  under  the
FCEF  is  based  on  a  demand  analysis,  taking  into  account  the  (i)  import  content  of  Pakistan
exports  as  derived  from  no-duty-no-drawback  data  (para.  25),  (ii)  exports  of  nontraditional
products that are particularly suited for SMEs, and (iii) average financing period. The Project is
expected  to  result  in  increasing  exports  by  around  $350  million  per  annum,  assuming  that  the
FCEF results in utilization of $100 million for additional exports (with an average turnaround of
three  times  per  annum)  and  $50  million  new  exports  by  SMEs  through  the  PEFG.  This  will

 30

support the creation of about 135,000 new jobs, assuming an output/worker ratio of PRs150,000
($2,600)  per  year,  although  this  is  even  lower  in  many  export  industries.  This  will  support  the
livelihood of about 1 million persons.

The  PRG  will  allow  exporters  to  get  cheaper  and  more  reliable  access  to  imports
147.
required  for  export  production,  at  terms  similar  to  international  competition.  The  PRG  will  also
ensure  that  disruption  of  vital  trade  flows  in  times  of  economic  or  political  crisis  will  be
minimized. The PRG will reduce volatility for L/C confirmation premiums, in particular for short
maturities that tend to be more volatile. The guarantee volume has been derived by analyzing
import  structures  as  well  as  L/C  confirmation  requirements,  although  actual  utilization  of  the
PRG  is  difficult  to  predict.  The  PRG  will  enhance  access  to  finance  and  reduce  cost,  but
utilization  of  this  enhancement  is  a  function  of  the  perception  of  Pakistan  country  risk  by  the
international  financial  community.  Similar  to  insurance,  low  utilization  of  the  PRG  will  be
considered  a  positive  sign,  but  it  is  important  to  put  the  instrument  in  place  to  reassure  the
market and have a facility in place should adverse events occur.

The PEFG will allow smaller or emerging export-related enterprises to get better access
148.
to  credit  and  free  up  collateral.  It  will  provide  additional  and  more  affordable  trade-related
finance. For participating banks, it offers a new form of collateral with lower risk weighting that
strengthens banks’ balance sheets. The PEFG will work with and through the banking system,
and  will  help  develop  new  and  existing  business  while  retaining  the  existing  banking
relationship.

149. ECAs  of  the  type  proposed  for  the  PEFG  are  often  a  steady  source  of  dividend  to  the
shareholder. Rates of return, measured on the basis of ratios of rate of return to return on equity
tend  to  be  in  the  same  category  as  other  public  goods  such  as  power  utilities  and  transport
networks.  The  PEFG’s  return  on  equity  are  expected  to  conform  to  this  basic  pattern,  with
consistent net profitability seen from three to four years of initial operation.

150.
The PEFG investment is expected to have a significant potential for capital appreciation
if  a  second  stage  of  financing    is  pursued  via  an  initial  public  offering  on  the  Karachi  Stock
Exchange or wider inclusion in one of the many emerging Asia-type mutual funds or unit trusts.

151.
Investment in the PEFG is a cost-effective way to leverage as much as $100 million in
new and nontraditional exporting activity from Pakistan through a $2 million equity investment, to
provide  much-needed  support  to  the  Pakistan  SME  sector,  and  by  so  doing,  make  a  direct
contribution to ADB’s stated policy goal of poverty reduction.

B.

Impact on Poverty and Social Dimensions

in 

the  SME  sector.  Like  most  entities 

The  most  direct  poverty  reduction  impact  of  the  FCEF  and  the  Project  will  be  through
152.
promoting  employment  creation 
in  Pakistan’s
manufacturing and industry sectors, SMEs have been affected negatively by sluggish economic
growth  and  in  particular  by  inadequate  access  to  trade  financing.  Clearly,  improved  access  to
the resources that limit both expansion and export market access will have a multiplier effect on
employment. Although Pakistan has had some success in reducing population growth rate to an
annual rate of increase of 2.3 percent, the country’s workforce will continue to grow by at least a
million workers per year. Pakistan’s population is young, and due to the momentum effect, will
not reach replacement levels for many years to come. Hence the need to create more jobs for
the young and expanding population is urgent. In Pakistan’s rural areas, where incomes tend to
be  lower,  considerable  unemployment  and  underemployment  exists.  Often  these  workers  are

 31

from landless families and, as such, can be considered to be poor. Expansion of the SME sector
will benefit this group. In addition, Pakistan’s two major urban areas, Lahore and Karachi, have
been growing rapidly, mainly due to high rates of rural to urban migration. SME growth in these
urban areas and in their peripheries (e.g. in the Sialkot-Gujranwala areas close to Lahore) will
provide a necessary boost to urban employment creation.

153. Promotion  of  the  SME  sector  through  the  Project  will  have  an  impact  on  women.
Although  official  data  on  women’s  labor  force  participation  tends  to  grossly  underestimate  the
role of women in the Pakistan economy (13.6 percent labor force participation), most women are
economically active in either the agriculture or informal sectors. In the Government’s Ninth Five-
Year  Plan  (1998-2003)  the  Government  committed  itself  to  promoting  women’s  employment
especially  in  certain  industries  (ready-made  garments,  electronics,  and  pharmaceuticals).
Women from the poorest households work as wage laborers in rural areas, and increasingly are
forced  by  economic  circumstances  to  do  so  in  urban  areas  as  well.  Increased  production  in
SMEs  concentrated  in  agriculture-based  activities  such  as  grain  milling,  cotton  weaving,  and
food  processing  will  benefit  female  wage  laborers  by  generating  increased  employment,  and
over time, higher incomes. Women also work in traditional SMEs such as those making carpets,
sporting  goods,  and  surgical  instruments.  Expansion  of  the  ready-made  garments  area  will
similarly open up new avenues of employment to women in SMEs.

154. Women’s wages lag behind those of men and often, especially in rural areas, women are
paid half of men’s wages for the same work or are employed as piece workers as home-based
workers  producing  for  the  SME  sector.    Increased  employment  opportunities  would  allow
Pakistan  women  to  have  other  options  for  work  outside  the  home  or  to  work  in  home-based
SMEs.  Similarly, rising labor demand will have a multiplier effect on real wages, a development
that should impact positively on women workers.

C.

Risks

155. Country risk. The short-term outlook for Pakistan is uncertain as the economic situation
remains  vulnerable.  Debt  service  is  high  and  the  balance  of  payments  is  weak.  Following  the
1998 crisis, Pakistan did reschedule its official debt under the Paris and London Club, but it did
not default nor reschedule its trade finance obligations. The balance of payment position slightly
improved since then. A credible economic adjustment remains crucial to preventing a balance of
payment  crisis  in  the  medium  term.  An  agreement  with  the  IMF  as  well  as  well  as  further
successful rescheduling of official debt in early 2001 will have positive implications.

156. Application  of  Islamic  banking  in  Pakistan.  In  December  1999,  a  Supreme  Court
judgement declared all forms of interest as tantamount to Riba and thus repugnant to Islam.  It
identified  specifically  the  statutes  that  should  become  void.    All  of  these  statutes  deal  with
domestic  banking.  International  financial  obligations  are  excluded  from  the  scope  of  the
Supreme  Court  ruling.    Accordingly,  international  financial  obligations  can  continue  on  an
interest-based  system  until  an  alternative  framework  is  devised  by  the  Government  and  is
accepted  by  the  international  lending  community.    Importantly,  trade  finance  transactions  that
are directly linked to an underlying asset are generally considered as “‘Islamic’.”

157. Policy reversal and loss of momentum. The principal risk associated with the Project
is that of policy reversal. To bring about sustained improvement, a long-term vision and strong
commitment  to  reform  and  development  is  required  in  a  number  of  areas.  Although  the
Government  has  expressed  a  clear  commitment  to  comprehensive  reform,  the  political  and
economic situation is fragile, and any measures cutting existing privileges of selected groups are

 32

subject  to  political  exploitation.  An  aggressive  communications  strategy  will  be  pursued,
including a series of consultative workshops to develop wider stakeholder support. The inclusion
of  private  sector  representation  in  the  various  project  components  makes  the  Project  less
vulnerable to changes in Government.

158.
Low  utilization  of  the  FCEF.  Some  of  the  risks  related  to  the  successful  introduction
and utilization of the FCEF include (i) delays in phasing subsidized lending under the EFS; (ii)
delays in establishing the PEFG; (iii) implementation of a countrywide information campaign to
educate exporters, indirect exporters, and participating banks about the FCEF and its potential
benefits, in conjunction with the PEFG public awareness campaign; (iv) creation of promotional
links  with  manufacturers  associations,  SMEDA,  and  EPB;  (v)  selection  of  an  export  credit
insurance provider to offer postshipment insurance linked to the FCEF; (vi) willingness of banks
to  accept  PEFG  guarantees  and  export  credit  insurance  in  place  of  collateral;  and  (vii)
successful training and interest of participating commercial banks.

159. Effective  and  sustainable  operation  of  the  PEFG.  The  following  principal  risks  are
associated with the PEFG:

(iv) 

Differing  investor  motives  and  shareholder  conflicts.  The  PEFG  is  expected  to  have  a
shareholder  structure  with  no  single  individual  investor  having  a  controlling  interest,
NPSBP will represent the sponsor group, accounting for about 50 percent of the capital
base.  While this will reduce the risk that PEFG operations may be directed to benefit a
single investor at the expense of smaller investors, the PEFG may lack strategic direction
if  NPBSP  members  fail  to  act  as  a  cohesive  group.  To  counter  this  risk,  the  NPSBP
member  banks  participating  in  the  PEFG  will  form  an  investor  group  and  enter  into  a
memorandum  of  understanding,  satisfactory  to  ADB,  detailing  how  issues  of  corporate
governance  and  conduct  of  NPBSP  member  banks  as  PEFG  investors  be  carried  out.
The PEFG will also develop a set of corporate governance policies regulating the duties
of investors and managers.

Inadequacies in PEFG’s management structure. Insufficient delegation of authority, from
the PEFG board to the PEFG chief executive officer and from the PEFG chief executive
officer to PEFG line management and staff could be a persistent concern. Description of
responsibilities  and  operational  manuals,  updated  on  a  regular  basis,  as  well  as
extensive use of IT can be expected to significantly address and minimize administrative
tendencies.

Inability  to  recruit  qualified  staff  to  PEFG.  To  address  this  possibility,  the  PEFG  will
provide competitive staff salaries equivalent to those of multinational banks and financial
institutions operating in Pakistan. A system of performance benchmarks and bonuses will
be developed to encourage all PEFG staff to perform at peak levels and be rewarded, as
a single team, for such activity.

Newness of the export finance guarantee concept insufficient understanding of the basic
principles. The PEFG will implement an active communication strategy and campaign to
explain  its  field  of  business  to  SMEs,    recognizing  that  the  PEFG  must  come  to  its
market,  following  ECA  best  practices  (e.g.,  Export  Development  Corporation,  Canada,
Export-Import  Bank  of  the  US).  One-on-one  sessions  with  participating  banks  and
selected export community stakeholders will explain the process of loan underwriting and
the coverage of the PEFG.

 33

(v) 

(vi) 

(vii) 

(viii) 

Inability of PEFG to operate in a fully market-responsive manner. To be successful, the
PEFG  must  be  able  to  advise  banks  and  applicants  in  a  manner  that  reflects  the  often
brief  turnaround  times  characteristic  of  international  trade.  The  PEFG  will  have  to  be
exempted  from  consideration  as  a  bank  or  nonbank  financial  institution  under  SBP
supervision, which allows greater operational flexibility.

Limitation on PEFG’s ability to seize foreign assets in the event of claims recovery. The
PEFG will seek clarification from SBP of the procedure to seize foreign assets, in order
to facilitate claim settlements. The PEFG will repatriate any and all such seized foreign
assets for conversion in Pakistan rupees.

Insufficient  sharing  of  information  between  banks,  other  agencies,  and  the  PEFG.  The
PEFG  will  reserve  the  right  to  cancel  a  guarantee  if  full  and  fair  disclosure  of  relevant
information is demonstrated to have been withheld by the originating bank or applicant.

Inability  of  banks  to  adapt  and  apply  IT  advances.  The  PEFG  will  have  to  play  a  lead
role,  when  necessary  to  encourage  banks  to  avail  of  the  benefits  of  IT  advances.  The
PEFG expects to play, if required, the role of applications services provider (ASP), on a
cost-recovery  or  breakeven  plus  basis.  The  imperatives  of  the  international  up-surge  in
e-commerce and the need to keep up with foreign demand requirements, combined with
the  incentive  to  access  PEFG  guarantee  products,  should  provide  sufficient  stimuli  to
overcome this constraint.

(ii) 

At  least  five  commercial  banks  in  Pakistan,  accounting  for  at  least  one  third  of

C. 

Conditions for PRG Effectiveness

162.

The following will be conditions for effectiveness of the PRG:

The  Government,  ADB,  and  the  facility  agent  will  have  signed  an  agency
agreement  in  a  form  satisfactory  to  ADB  whereby  the  parties  agree  that  the
facility  agent  will  act  as  the  agent  of  ADB  and  the  Government  in  administering
the PRG;

The Government will have duly executed and delivered a counterguarantee and
indemnity agreement in a form satisfactory to ADB;

At least one confirming bank will have signed an MRPA; and

The front-end fee will be paid.

D. 

Conditions for Disbursement to PEFG

The following are the conditions of disbursement for the first call for capital on the PEFG

163.
equity investment:

The PEFG will be established as a public limited company under the Companies’
Ordinance  and  have  a  minimum  paid-in  initial  capital  of  $2  million  (including
ADB’s commitment), or commitments for such capital;

A  chief  executive  officer  and  senior  management  acceptable  to  ADB  are
recruited by the PEFG;

A  risk  management  manual  and  governance  manual  satisfactory  to  ADB  will  be
developed for the PEFG and put in place, and the PEFG will have constituted an
audit and conflicts committee;

The  PEFG  will  have  a  code  of  conduct  for  directors,  officers,  and  staff  of  the
company dealing with conflict of interest, confidentiality, and other such issues;

SBP will confirm that (i) the PEFG is not a bank or a nonbank financial institution
and is not subject to SBP regulation; (ii) the PEFG guarantee will carry a low risk
weighting, acceptable to ADB, for the purposes of commercial banks’ compliance
with  prudential  banking  regulations;  (iii)  no  restrictions  exist  for  the  PEFG
maintaining a 5:1 gearing ratio per trade cycle; and (iv) the PEFG is not restricted

IMPLEMENTATION PROCEDURES FOR DISBURSEMNT OF THE
FOREIGN CURRENCY EXPORT FINANCE (FCEF) FACILITY

1.
SPB  will  issue  regulations  for  use  of  the  FCEF.  The  regulations,  which  will  be  widely
publicized  and  promoted,  should  set  out  the  procedures  to  be  followed  when  drawing  on  the
FCEF window, including the following steps:

(i) 

The  direct  exporter  (DE)  or  indirect  exporter/supplier  (IDE)  submits  a  standard
application form to PEFG or a PCB.1 The DE or IDE may go through PEFG as a
one-stop  shop  when  it  needs  to  utilize  some  or  all  of  the  credit  enhancement
facilities. The application will include:

(a) 

(b) 

a copy of the relevant export order, and, in the case of an IDE, proof of a
purchase order from an exporter (the purchase order must be linked to an
export order);

the  method  of  payment  (letter  of  credit,  document  acceptance  open
account), currency and credit period of the export order (and the purchase
order, if applicable); and

(c) 

details required on inputs, i.e., domestic or direct imports.

(ii)

(iii)

(iv)

Where the method of payment is by irrevocable letter of credit, the issuing bank
has  to  be  of  acceptable  credit  quality  to  the  PCB/PEFG;  where  the  method  of
payment  is  by  open  account  or  documentary  payment  or  acceptance:  credit
insurance is required, as available, to establish security; and credit limits on the
foreign buyers will be established by the PCB and/or PEFG.

The amount of an advance under the FCEF for preshipment financing will be up
to a maximum of 80 percent of the value of the export order (or 100 percent of the
cost,  insurance,  freight  value  of  the  input  goods,  whichever  is  less)  and  for
postshipment financing up to 80 percent of the value of the export order (or 100
percent if payment is by irrevocable letter of credit).

The  application  will  be  approved  by  PEFG  or  the  PCB  and  once  approved,
submitted to SBP for confirmation that funds are available.  SBP will also ensure
that the individual PCB limits and the ceiling for non-small and medium enterprise
exporters will not be breached.  SBP will confirm funds available within 48 hours.

(v)

Upon confirmation of availability of funds, export contract (and purchase order, if
applicable) is assigned to PEFG or PCB, as the case may be.

                                                
1  The application form will be simple and is based on the application under the proposed  Duty and Tax
Remission for Export (DTRE) Rules and will include the export order identification number assigned by
customs under these rules, if applicable.

(vii)

Appendix 5, page 2

When  a  PEFG  guarantee  is  being  utilized,  PEFG  then  issues  the  guarantee  in
favor of the PCB to enable it to issue an import letter of credit to cover the import
element of the export order.

If  required  by  a  domestic  supplier,  PEFG  may  issue  a  conditional  guarantee  or
promissory  note  to  the  domestic  supplier  (i.e.,  indirect  exporter)  to  cover  the
payment  risk  that  the  direct  exporter  will  pay.    The  cost  would  be  borne  by  the
domestic supplier.

(viii)

The  import  letter  of  credit  is  issued  by  the  importer’s  bank  upon  receipt  of
confirmation  from  SBP  that  funds  are  available,  and  receipt  of  the  PEFG
guarantee when required.

The  goods  are  shipped  under  the  import  letter  of  credit  or  received  from  the
domestic market and settlement is made from FCEF funds.

The purchase order or the export order is completed.  Prior to export, the buyer or
its  nominated  agent  conducts  a  preshipment  inspection  of  the  goods  to  be
exported.  A preshipment inspection certificate is issued.

Once the goods are shipped, evidence of shipment and acceptance of the quality
of  goods  by  the  buyer  or  nominated  agent  is  lodged  with  PEFG  or  the  PCB.
Documents are lodged under letter of credit, if applicable or sent on a collection
basis.

Postshipment finance is provided from the FCEF up to a maximum of 100 percent
of  the  value  of  the  export  order.    If  the  payment  method  is  irrevocable  letter  of
credit, 100 percent of the value may be financed. If the payment method is on a
collection basis or open account, the PCB may finance 80 percent of the value if
there is a PEFG guarantee, which would be backed by credit insurance.

(xiii)

Repayment  of  the  FCEF  from  settlement  of  export  letter  of  credit  or  payment
under export order.

TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE FOR INSTITUTIONAL STRENGTHENING OF
EXPORT PROMOTION BUREAU

A.

Rationale and Objectives

Export  Promotion  Bureau  (EPB)  was  established  as  an  attached  department  of  the
1.
Ministry  of  Commerce  in  1963  to  promote  sustainable  growth  of  the  quantity  and  value  of
exports of goods and services. EPB currently has over a dozen offices throughout Pakistan with
the  head  office  located  in  Karachi.  The  head  office  and  its  regional  offices  employ  over  1,200
personnel in total (of which about 120 are professional staff).

2.
The  main  functions  of  EPB  include  formulating  and  administering  export  policies;
engaging  in  market  development  activities  by  participating  in  and  arranging  trade  fairs;
organizing trade delegations; conducting research and seminars on specific export products and
more general economic issues such as ISO 9000 and World Trade Organization (WTO)-related
issues; managing Pakistan product display centers at Islamabad, Karachi, Lahore, Multan, and
Peshawar;  and  managing  the  textile  quotas  in  which  the  control  function  conflicts  with  the
organization’s promotional brief.

3.
EPB is frequently criticized by the private sector for not being able to perform its role of
promoting Pakistan’s exports in international markets effectively. In spite of the various attempts
to  reform  EPB,  EPB  has  in  the  past  failed  to  establish  itself  in  the  eye  of  the  public  as  a
proactive  agency  in  export  promotion  and  trade  facilitation.  Instead,  EPB  has  been  heavily
burdened with regulatory and administrative work. Its research work has been done more often
on an ad hoc basis and is often unable to provide meaningful data when requested. Most of the
recommendations  of  the  completed  research  have  not  been  acted  on  by  the  Government.  Its
vertical  administrative  structure  has  been  ineffective  in  motivating  EPB  staff,  and  some  of  the
display centers are in  very poor condition.

Restructuring of EPB in promoting Pakistan exports and export facilitation schemes has
4.
been identified as an important area for export promotion, including dissemination of the various
export  schemes  being  developed  under  the  TEPI  Program  and  the  Small  and  Medium
Enterprise Trade Enhancement Finance (SMETEF) Project. Recently, EPB conducted at its own
initiative,  a  thorough  analysis  of  the  strength  and  weakness  of  Pakistan  exports,  and  of  EPB’s
role in facilitating exports. Based on the analysis, EPB has prepared a vision plan and an export
strategy, with the objective of achieving the export target of $10 billion by 2003.

The  export  strategy,  though  still  in  the  process  of  finalization,  spells  out  six  areas  that
5.
EPB will pursue to help exporters. This includes making efforts to maximize the market share for
Pakistan’s existing products, conduct value addition audit for the main export products, focus on
nontraditional  areas,  identify  geographic  gaps,  enhance  government  to  government  and
government  to  business  relationships,  and  capitalize  strategic  trade  alliances.  All  these  efforts
aim to induce an export culture and create an exporter friendly regulatory environment. EPB has
also  taken  steps  to  examine  the  human  resource  development  aspect  and  completed  a  staff
survey  to  solicit  their  views  on  EPB.  These  are  very  encouraging  developments  and  the
Government has requested ADB assistance to support these initiatives. During discussions with
ADB, the EPB chair and senior management expressed strong support and responsiveness for
ADB assistance for EPB capacity building.

 56

Appendix 9, page 2

6.
The  TA  supports  EPB  restructuring  and  capacity  building  with  the  objective  of
transforming  it  into  an  effective  body  for  trade  facilitation,  export  promotion,  and  inward
investment.  To  achieve  the  TA  objective,  activities  will  build  on  the  existing  work  that  is  being
undertaken  by  EPB  and  concentrate  on  operationalizing  the  various  recommendations  being
formulated.

SOCIAL AND POVERTY ANALYSIS

A.

Poverty in Pakistan – An overview

1. 
From  an  historical  perspective,  Pakistan  successfully  reduced  poverty  over  the  five
decades  since  independence.  Absolute  poverty,  based  on  caloric  intake,  declined  from  46.5
percent  in  1969/70  to  17  percent  in  1987/88.  Since  then,  however,  a  substantial  reversal  has
taken  place.  Most  recent  research  suggests  a  substantial  rise  in  poverty  to  35  percent  in
1998/99.  This  deterioration  has  been  experienced  both  by  rural  as  well  as  urban  areas.
Pakistan’s poverty rate, using the basic needs approach, recounts a similar story, illustrating a
rise from 29 percent of the population living in poverty in 1986/87 to 38 percent in 1998/99.

2. 
In  the  1990s  the  Pakistan  economy  gradually  stagnated  as  annual  gross  domestic
product  (GDP)  growth  declined  to  4.4  percent.  This  was  accompanied  by  a  steep  cut  in
development expenditure and a downsizing of many government services. Remittances declined
by  over  40  percent  during  1982-1996.  Since  1998,  after  the  nuclear  tests  and  the  subsequent
freeze  on  foreign  currency  accounts,  foreign  remittances  have  dipped.  In  addition,  food
subsidies have declined from 2 percent of GDP in 1988/89 to 0.5 percent in 1996/97. Under the
rationalized tax structure with disproportionate reliance on indirect taxes, relatively more burden
seems to have been shifted to the poor. Government antipoverty programs alone are insufficient
to  reverse  these  trends.  Spending  on  safety  nets  is  meager  and  has  not  increased
proportionately  to  rises  in  poverty.  Above  all,  the  failure  to  generate  sufficient  employment
opportunities to arrest high unemployment levels has had a negative impact on poverty.

B.

Income Distribution

Since the 1960s, income inequality has tended to be moderate, with the Gini coefficient
3. 
of household income often around 0.35 or below. From the mid-1960s until the late 1980s, the
Gini  coefficient  and  the  income  share  of  the  bottom  quintile  changed  very  little.  The  Gini
coefficient  peaked  at  0.40  in  1990/91  and  the  income  share  of  the  bottom  20  percent  of
households  fell  to  just  5.7  percent,  after  having  been  typically  in  the  range  7.5  to  8.0  percent
over  the  1970s  and  1980s.  Since  then,  most  observers  agree  that  the  Gini  coefficient  shows
growing  inequality  in  income  distribution.  Analyses  of  the  impact  of  structural  adjustment
programs  on  Pakistan  determine  that  reduced  public  expenditure  on  the  social  sector  coupled
with the withdrawal of subsidies had a highly negative impact on income distribution. Increased
efforts  for  revenue  generation  with  disproportionate  emphasis  on  the  general  sales  tax  (GST)
and  regulatory  duties  may  have  rendered  the  taxation  structure  more  regressive  in  character.
High unemployment  with attendant  stagnation or declining real wages has likely contributed to
worsening income distribution in Pakistan.

C.

Labor Market Trends

During the 1990s, unemployment, underemployment, and precarious jobs have emerged
4. 
as serious labor market issues in Pakistan. The slowdown of economic growth during the 1990s
has led to increasing problems of unemployment and underemployment.  The pattern of growth
and  structural  change  in  the  economy  has  led  to  a  labor  market  characterized  by  declining
employment  in  agriculture  and  manufacturing,  and  by  a  small  but  productive  large-scale
manufacturing  sector  and  a  growing  but  less  efficient  small-scale  sector.    As  a  result  of  the
ongoing

 60

Appendix 10, page 2

ongoing  economic  crisis,  rising  unemployment  and  the  increasing  size  of  the  informal  sector,
real wage increases have been weak and poverty and inequality have grown.

5. 
Female  labor  force  participation  rates  are  low  but  recent  estimates  show  that  when
women’s  work  as  unpaid  family  laborers  is  included,  their  contribution  to  the  labor  force  is
actually much higher than previously thought. The result has been an increase in female labor
force  participation  rates  from  14  percent  to  38  percent.    In  particular,  women’s  contribution  to
both rural and urban manufacturing and to the construction industry is especially high.

6. 
In Pakistan, the rate of employment of child labor can be directly correlated to poverty.
Low  household  income  tends  to  increase  child  labor.    Other  factors  include  lack  of  school
availability, and inflexible wage rates for adult labor and monitoring.  The growth of the informal
sector in Pakistan over the 1990s, coupled with growing household poverty levels has facilitated
rather than constrained child labor.  However, factors such as high growth during the 1980s and
efforts  under  the  Government  Social  Action  Program  (SAP)  to  universalize  primary  school
attendance have helped temper the growth of child labor.  Overall, the result of these interacting
factors has been that the labor force participation rates for children between the ages of 10 to 14
has  virtually  halved  from  1982  to  1997  from  22  percent  to  12  percent.    Much  of  child  labor  in
Pakistan  is  rural  farm  labor,  although  some  children  are  employed  in  the  informal  and  SME
sectors.

D.

Potential Poverty Impact of the SME Sector

7. 
The provision of employment is one of the most important challenges facing sustainable
poverty  reduction  in  Pakistan.  In  the  face  of  declining  growth  of  the  large-scale  manufacturing
sector,  SMEs  have  been  increasing  their  importance  to  the  Pakistan  economy.    Traditional
sectors such as agriculture and large-scale manufacturing have declining abilities to absorb the
country’s  surplus  labor.  The  SME  sector  has  the  potential  to  support  poverty  reduction  by
absorbing excess labor in the  rural  and urban areas of the economy. Many of the new jobs in
this  sector  do  not  require  high  levels  of  literacy  although  Pakistan’s  low  levels  of  human
development do constrain the emergence of SMEs in modern sectors. According to SMEDA, as
many as 1.8 million jobs could be created in SMEs in five key sectors during 2000-2005.  These
sectors are textiles, leather, dairy, marble, and fisheries; all have considerable export potential,
especially textiles, leather, and marble.

8. 
Overall,  unemployment  in  Pakistan  has  been  estimated  to  be  around  20  percent  of  the
population of working age. (three-year development plan) and underemployment is even higher.
The recent growth of the number of SMEs in services is a response to growing unemployment
and  underemployment.  Employment  elasticities  in  all  major  sectors  such  as  agriculture,
manufacturing  and  services  are  low.  Of  the  approximately  1.3  million  new  workers  who  are
added to Pakistan’s labor force every year, approximately 40 percent face unemployment.   The
labor force is estimated to increase from 38.2 million in 1997/98 to 43.9 million by 2002/03, the
problem of unemployment is likely to intensity in the coming years. Yet another disturbing trend
is  the  lack  of  employment  opportunities  for  the  educated;  unemployment  rates  are  highest  for
recent  graduates.  The  SME  sector  is  already  absorbing  many  of  these  workers  but  more
expansion is required to increase its ability to absorb surplus labor.

 61

Appendix 10, page 3

9. 
Analyses of the household and income expenditure survey cross-sectional data suggests
that the higher the number of earners in a household, the lower is the level of probability that the
household will be engulfed in poverty. In this context SME development because of its potentials
for employment promotion and growth constitutes an important policy initiative for Pakistan. The
capital  to  labor  ratio  in  the  SME  sector,  on  average,  is  one  fourth  that  for  large-scale
manufacturing  industries.  Ease  of  entry  into  the  sector  is  relatively  low  although  export
opportunities  are  more  difficult  for  SMEs  due  to  the  absence  of  information  coupled  with  the
difficulties associated with access to foreign markets.

10. 
Generally,  employment  in  the  SME  sector  in  Pakistan  can  be  divided  into  three  main
groups: microenterprises (home-based industries with less than 10 employees), traditional SMEs
(with  11  to  100  employees)  in  sectors  such  as  weaving  and  textiles,  carpets,  sporting  goods,
and surgical instruments; and modern SMEs (11 to 100 employees) in emerging sectors such as
auto parts manufacturing, metals, chemicals, and ready-made garments.  While all three groups
demonstrate  considerable  employment  potential,  only  the  modern  SME  sector  can  be
considered  a  higher  productivity  sector.  Some  activities,  such  as  weaving,  are  present  in  both
modern and traditional SMEs and, with the utilization of product differentiation, could appeal to
entirely  different  markets.    Similarly,  the  cottage  industry  or  handicrafts  sector  includes  both
microenterprises  and traditional SMEs with high employment potential. However productivity is
low and considerable efforts are needed to improve aspects such as design, product quality, and
marketing.

11.  While the SME sector can play a crucial role in reducing poverty by fostering economic
growth  and  employment  promotion,  constraints  limit  the  expansion  of  SME  employment.  The
existing  SME  structure,  dominated  by  traditional  rural-based  industries  like  food,  wood,  and
textiles shows slow growth in nontraditional or modern industries like auto parts manufacturing,
pharmaceuticals,  chemicals,  and  ready-made  garments  for  exports.  Small-scale  producers  are
generally handicapped by the lack of export demand for their products. In addition, because of
the low quality of many goods produced, SMEs are not competitive in the export market and only
constitute  a  small  proportion  of  Pakistan’s  exports.  For  example,  two  of  Pakistan’s  most
successful traditional SME exporters, surgical instruments and sporting goods, account for only
4.6 percent of manufacturing exports. Facilities for testing, grading, and quality control have to
be  provided  to  SME  producers.  The  export  market  to  must  be  linked  to  SMEs  through  the
provision of information on specifications, patterns of demand, and product quality. This will not
only  lead  to  poverty  reduction  through  higher  employment  and  economic  growth,  but  will  also
promote investments and employment creation in the modern SME sector.

E.

Gender in the SME Sector

12. 
Although official data on women’s labor force participation tends to grossly underestimate
the  real  role  of  women  in  the  Pakistan  economy  (13.6  percent  labor  force  participation),  most
women  are  economically  active  in  the  agriculture,  service,  or  informal  sectors.  Anecdotal
evidence  indicates  growing  female  employment  in  the  formal  sectors,  largely  in  response  to
growing poverty. Women’s employment can make a valuable contribution to household income.
In  the  three-year  development  program  (2000-2003)  the  Government  has  committed  to
promoting  women’s  employment  especially  in  certain  rural-based  industries  where  women  are
already  economically  active.  These  include  agriculture  and  livestock  production.  Women  from
the  poorest  households  work  as  wage  laborers  in  rural  areas  and,  increasingly  are  forced  by
economic circumstances to do so in urban areas as well. The SME sector offers relative ease of

 62

Appendix 10, page 4

entry  and  provides  viable  employment  opportunities  for  women,  the  majority  of  whom  are
illiterate  and  unskilled.  Increased  SME  production  is  concentrated  in  traditional,  agriculture-
based activities such as grain milling, cotton weaving, and food processing  and benefits female
wage  laborers  by  generating  increased  employment  and,  over  time,  higher  incomes.    Women
also  work  in  traditional  SMEs  such  as  those  producing  carpets,  sporting  goods,  and  surgical
instruments.  Expansion  of  the  readymade  garments  sector  will  open  up  new  avenues  of
employment to women in modern SMEs.

13.  Women’s wages lag those for men and often, especially in rural areas, women are paid
half of what men are paid for the same work or are employed as piece workers as home-based
workers  producing  for  the  SME  sector.  In  Karachi,  many  women  work  in  the  shrimp-peeling
industry. Increased employment opportunities would allow women to have other options for work
outside the home or to work in home-based SMEs. Similarly, rising labor demand will also have
a  multiplier  effect  on  real  wages,  a  development  that  should  impact  positively  on  women
workers.

F.

Labor Standards

The SME sector in Pakistan is well known for not adhering to labor standards, particularly
14. 
for  children,  bonded  laborers,  and  women.  Generally,  when  poverty  is  high,  child  labor,  in
particular,  tends  to  increase.  However,  in  the  last  decade  and  a  half  child  labor  has  actually
fallen by half partially due to strong efforts by the Government to promote universal education.

15. 
Strong  efforts  are  under  way  by  the  Government  to  better  address  labor  standards.  A
special cell within the Federal Ministry of Labour was established to revise and refine more than
100 labor laws, some of which date back to the 19th century. A labor policy will be released by
the end of 2000, and a new set of revised, refined, and updated labor laws will be prepared by
mid-2001.  In addition, the Government has affirmed its commitment to the eradication of child
labor  and  the  protection  of  the  rights  of  working  women  in  policy  documents  such  as  the
National  Policy  and  Action  Plan  to  Combat  Child  Labor  and  the  Three-Year  Development
Program 2000-2003.  Once a labor policy and revised laws are in place then enforcement and
implementation will be a Government priority.

16. 
The International Labor Organization (ILO) and other development agencies, notably the
United States Department of Labor are providing strong support to the Government’s efforts to
combat child labor.  A number of industries in the traditional SME sector have been targeted and
are  receiving  support.  These  include  the  sporting  goods  industry,  surgical  instruments,  auto
repair,  brick-making,  and  carpet  weaving.  Other  interventions  are  planned  and  Pakistan  is
scheduled to sign the ILO convention against child labor (Conventions 182 and 183) in the near
future.  Other areas of concern include the provision of minimum wages, bonded laborers, and
working conditions especially for women and other vulnerable groups.
